LCOV - code coverage report
Current view: top level - src/bin/pg_dump - pg_dump.c (source / functions) Hit Total Coverage
Test: PostgreSQL 17devel Lines: 6892 7679 89.8 %
Date: 2024-02-13 10:46:01 Functions: 172 176 97.7 %
Legend: Lines: hit not hit 

          Line data    Source code
       1             : /*-------------------------------------------------------------------------
       2             :  *
       3             :  * pg_dump.c
       4             :  *    pg_dump is a utility for dumping out a postgres database
       5             :  *    into a script file.
       6             :  *
       7             :  * Portions Copyright (c) 1996-2024, PostgreSQL Global Development Group
       8             :  * Portions Copyright (c) 1994, Regents of the University of California
       9             :  *
      10             :  *  pg_dump will read the system catalogs in a database and dump out a
      11             :  *  script that reproduces the schema in terms of SQL that is understood
      12             :  *  by PostgreSQL
      13             :  *
      14             :  *  Note that pg_dump runs in a transaction-snapshot mode transaction,
      15             :  *  so it sees a consistent snapshot of the database including system
      16             :  *  catalogs. However, it relies in part on various specialized backend
      17             :  *  functions like pg_get_indexdef(), and those things tend to look at
      18             :  *  the currently committed state.  So it is possible to get 'cache
      19             :  *  lookup failed' error if someone performs DDL changes while a dump is
      20             :  *  happening. The window for this sort of thing is from the acquisition
      21             :  *  of the transaction snapshot to getSchemaData() (when pg_dump acquires
      22             :  *  AccessShareLock on every table it intends to dump). It isn't very large,
      23             :  *  but it can happen.
      24             :  *
      25             :  *  http://archives.postgresql.org/pgsql-bugs/2010-02/msg00187.php
      26             :  *
      27             :  * IDENTIFICATION
      28             :  *    src/bin/pg_dump/pg_dump.c
      29             :  *
      30             :  *-------------------------------------------------------------------------
      31             :  */
      32             : #include "postgres_fe.h"
      33             : 
      34             : #include <unistd.h>
      35             : #include <ctype.h>
      36             : #include <limits.h>
      37             : #ifdef HAVE_TERMIOS_H
      38             : #include <termios.h>
      39             : #endif
      40             :

     967             :      *

     969             :      * the initial sort is mostly for cosmetic purposes: we sort by name to
     970             :      * ensure that logically identical schemas will dump identically.
     971             :      */
     972         294 :     sortDumpableObjectsByTypeName(dobjs, numObjs);
     973             : 
     974         294 :     sortDumpableObjects(dobjs, numObjs,
     975         294 :                         boundaryObjs[0].dumpId, boundaryObjs[1].dumpId);

     977             :     /*
     978             :      * Create archive TOC entries for all the objects to be dumped, in a safe
     979             :      * order.

     981             :

     985         294 :     dumpEncoding(fout);

     989             :     /* The database items are always next, unless we don't want them at all */

    1284             :     /*
    1285             :      * To support the combination of serializable_deferrable with the jobs
    1286             :      * option we use REPEATABLE READ for the worker connections that are
    1287             :      * passed a snapshot.  As long as the snapshot is acquired in a
    1288             :      * SERIALIZABLE, READ ONLY, DEFERRABLE transaction, its use within a
    1289             :      * REPEATABLE READ transaction provides the appropriate integrity
    1290             :      * guarantees.  This is a kluge, but safe for back-patching.
    1291             :      */
    1292         356 :     if (dopt->serializable_deferrable && AH->sync_snapshot_id == NULL)

    1294             :                             "SET TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL "

    1327             : static void
    1328          28 : setupDumpWorker(Archive *AH)

    1356             : static ArchiveFormat
    1357         346 : parseArchiveFormat(const char *format, ArchiveMode *mode)
    1358             : {
    1359             :     ArchiveFormat archiveFormat;

    1361         346 :     *mode = archModeWrite;

    1363         346 :     if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "a") == 0 || pg_strcasecmp(format, "append") == 0)
    1364             :     {

    1367          86 :         *mode = archModeAppend;
    1368             :     }

    1370           8 :         archiveFormat = archCustom;
    1371         252 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "custom") == 0)
    1372          28 :         archiveFormat = archCustom;
    1373         224 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "d") == 0)
    1374          14 :         archiveFormat = archDirectory;
    1375         210 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "directory") == 0)
    1376           4 :         archiveFormat = archDirectory;
    1377         206 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "p") == 0)
    1378         194 :         archiveFormat = archNull;
    1379          12 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "plain") == 0)
    1380           4 :         archiveFormat = archNull;
    1381           8 :     else if (pg_strcasecmp(format, "t") == 0)
    1382           4 :         archiveFormat = archTar;

    1384           2 :         archiveFormat = archTar;
    1385             :     else
    1386           2 :         pg_fatal("invalid output format \"%s\" specified", format);
    1387         344 :     return archiveFormat;

    1389             : 
    1390             : /*
    1391             :  * Find the OIDs of all schemas matching the given list of patterns,
    1392             :  * and append them to the given OID list.
    1393             :  */
    1394             : static void
    1395         346 : expand_schema_name_patterns(Archive *fout,
    1396             :                             SimpleStringList *patterns,
    1397             :                             SimpleOidList *oids,
    1398             :                             bool strict_names)

    1648             : /*
    1649             :  * Verifies that the connected database name matches the given database name,
    1650             :  * and if not, dies with an error about the given pattern.
    1651             :  *
    1652             :  * The 'dbname' argument should be a literal name parsed from 'pattern'.
    1653             :  */
    1654             : static void
    1655          10 : prohibit_crossdb_refs(PGconn *conn, const char *dbname, const char *pattern)
    1656             : {
    1657             :     const char *db;
    1658             : 
    1659          10 :     db = PQdb(conn);
    1660          10 :     if (db == NULL)
    1661           0 :         pg_fatal("You are currently not connected to a database.");
    1662             : 
    1663          10 :     if (strcmp(db, dbname) != 0)
    1664          10 :         pg_fatal("cross-database references are not implemented: %s",
    1665             :                  pattern);
    1666           0 : }
    1667             : 
    1668             : /*
    1669             :  * checkExtensionMembership
    1670             :  *      Determine whether object is an extension member, and if so,
    1671             :  *      record an appropriate dependency and set the object's dump flag.
    1672             :  *
    1673             :  * It's important to call this for each object that could be an extension
    1674             :  * member.  Generally, we integrate this with determining the object's
    1675             :  * to-be-dumped-ness, since extension membership overrides other rules for that.
    1676             :  *
    1677             :  * Returns true if object is an extension member, else false.
    1678             :  */
    1679             : static bool
    1680      907880 : checkExtensionMembership(DumpableObject *dobj, Archive *fout)
    1681             : {
    1682      907880 :     ExtensionInfo *ext = findOwningExtension(dobj->catId);
    1683             : 
    1684      907880 :     if (ext == NULL)
    1685      906812 :         return false;
    1686             : 
    1687        1068 :     dobj->ext_member = true;
    1688             : 
    1689             :     /* Record dependency so that getDependencies needn't deal with that */
    1690        1068 :     addObjectDependency(dobj, ext->dobj.dumpId);
    1691             : 
    1692             :     /*
    1693             :      * In 9.6 and above, mark the member object to have any non-initial ACLs
    1694             :      * dumped.  (Any initial ACLs will be removed later, using data from
    1695             :      * pg_init_privs, so that we'll dump only the delta from the extension's
    1696             :      * initial setup.)
    1697             :      *
    1698             :      * Prior to 9.6, we do not include any extension member components.
    1699             :      *
    1700             :      * In binary upgrades, we still dump all components of the members
    1701             :      * individually, since the idea is to exactly reproduce the database
    1702             :      * contents rather than replace the extension contents with something
    1703             :      * different.
    1704             :      *
    1705             :      * Note: it might be interesting someday to implement storage and delta
    1706             :      * dumping of extension members' RLS policies and/or security labels.
    1707             :      * However there is a pitfall for RLS policies: trying to dump them
    1708             :      * requires getting a lock on their tables, and the calling user might not
    1709             :      * have privileges for that.  We need no lock to examine a table's ACLs,
    1710             :      * so the current feature doesn't have a problem of that sort.
    1711             :      */
    1712        1068 :     if (fout->dopt->binary_upgrade)
    1713         142 :         dobj->dump = ext->dobj.dump;
    1714             :     else
    1715             :     {
    1716         926 :         if (fout->remoteVersion < 90600)
    1717           0 :             dobj->dump = DUMP_COMPONENT_NONE;
    1718             :         else
    1719         926 :             dobj->dump = ext->dobj.dump_contains & (DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL);
    1720             :     }
    1721             : 
    1722        1068 :     return true;
    1723             : }
    1724             : 
    1725             : /*
    1726             :  * selectDumpableNamespace: policy-setting subroutine

    1730        1788 : selectDumpableNamespace(NamespaceInfo *nsinfo, Archive *fout)
    1731             : {

    1768             :     {
    1769             :         /*
    1770             :          * The public schema is a strange beast that sits in a sort of
    1771             :          * no-mans-land between being a system object and a user object.
    1772             :          * CREATE SCHEMA would fail, so its DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION is just
    1773             :          * a comment and an indication of ownership.  If the owner is the
    1774             :          * default, omit that superfluous DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION.  Before
    1775             :          * v15, the default owner was BOOTSTRAP_SUPERUSERID.
    1776             :          */
    1777         248 :         nsinfo->create = false;

    1801             :     /*

    1803             :      * override the dump decision for the schema itself.  However, this does

    1808        1788 :     (void) checkExtensionMembership(&nsinfo->dobj, fout);

    1811             : /*
    1812             :  * selectDumpableTable: policy-setting subroutine

    1815             : static void
    1816       74168 : selectDumpableTable(TableInfo *tbinfo, Archive *fout)

    1818       74168 :     if (checkExtensionMembership(&tbinfo->dobj, fout))

    1825       73754 :     if (table_include_oids.head != NULL)

    1840             : 
    1841             : /*
    1842             :  * selectDumpableType: policy-setting subroutine
    1843             :  *      Mark a type as to be dumped or not
    1844             :  *
    1845             :  * If it's a table's rowtype or an autogenerated array type, we also apply a
    1846             :  * special type code to facilitate sorting into the desired order.  (We don't
    1847             :  * want to consider those to be ordinary types because that would bring tables
    1848             :  * up into the datatype part of the dump order.)  We still set the object's
    1849             :  * dump flag; that's not going to cause the dummy type to be dumped, but we
    1850             :  * need it so that casts involving such types will be dumped correctly -- see
    1851             :  * dumpCast.  This means the flag should be set the same as for the underlying
    1852             :  * object (the table or base type).
    1853             :  */
    1854             : static void
    1855      205156 : selectDumpableType(TypeInfo *tyinfo, Archive *fout)
    1856             : {
    1857             :     /* skip complex types, except for standalone composite types */
    1858      205156 :     if (OidIsValid(tyinfo->typrelid) &&
    1859       72954 :         tyinfo->typrelkind != RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)
    1860             :     {
    1861       72688 :         TableInfo  *tytable = findTableByOid(tyinfo->typrelid);
    1862             : 
    1863       72688 :         tyinfo->dobj.objType = DO_DUMMY_TYPE;
    1864       72688 :         if (tytable != NULL)
    1865       72688 :             tyinfo->dobj.dump = tytable->dobj.dump;
    1866             :         else
    1867           0 :             tyinfo->dobj.dump = DUMP_COMPONENT_NONE;
    1868       72688 :         return;
    1869             :     }
    1870             : 
    1871             :     /* skip auto-generated array types */
    1872      132468 :     if (tyinfo->isArray || tyinfo->isMultirange)
    1873             :     {
    1874      100234 :         tyinfo->dobj.objType = DO_DUMMY_TYPE;
    1875             : 
    1876             :         /*
    1877             :          * Fall through to set the dump flag; we assume that the subsequent
    1878             :          * rules will do the same thing as they would for the array's base
    1879             :          * type.  (We cannot reliably look up the base type here, since
    1880             :          * getTypes may not have processed it yet.)

    2098             : static int
    2099        6300 : dumpTableData_copy(Archive *fout, const void *dcontext)
    2100             : {
    2101        6300 :     TableDataInfo *tdinfo = (TableDataInfo *) dcontext;
    2102        6300 :     TableInfo  *tbinfo = tdinfo->tdtable;
    2103        6300 :     const char *classname = tbinfo->dobj.name;
    2104        6300 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();
    2105             : 
    2106             :     /*
    2107             :      * Note: can't use getThreadLocalPQExpBuffer() here, we're calling fmtId
    2108             :      * which uses it already.
    2109             :      */
    2110        6300 :     PQExpBuffer clistBuf = createPQExpBuffer();
    2111        6300 :     PGconn     *conn = GetConnection(fout);
    2112             :     PGresult   *res;
    2113             :     int         ret;
    2114             :     char       *copybuf;
    2115             :     const char *column_list;
    2116             : 
    2117        6300 :     pg_log_info("dumping contents of table \"%s.%s\"",
    2118             :                 tbinfo->dobj.namespace->dobj.name, classname);
    2119             : 
    2120             :     /*
    2121             :      * Specify the column list explicitly so that we have no possibility of
    2122             :      * retrieving data in the wrong column order.  (The default column
    2123             :      * ordering of COPY will not be what we want in certain corner cases
    2124             :      * involving ADD COLUMN and inheritance.)
    2125             :      */
    2126        6300 :     column_list = fmtCopyColumnList(tbinfo, clistBuf);
    2127             : 
    2128             :     /*
    2129             :      * Use COPY (SELECT ...) TO when dumping a foreign table's data, and when
    2130             :      * a filter condition was specified.  For other cases a simple COPY
    2131             :      * suffices.
    2132             :      */
    2133        6300 :     if (tdinfo->filtercond || tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE)
    2134             :     {
    2135           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "COPY (SELECT ");
    2136             :         /* klugery to get rid of parens in column list */
    2137           2 :         if (strlen(column_list) > 2)
    2138             :         {
    2139           2 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, column_list + 1);
    2140           2 :             q->data[q->len - 1] = ' ';
    2141             :         }
    2142             :         else
    2143           0 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "* ");
    2144             :

    2146           2 :                           fmtQualifiedDumpable(tbinfo),
    2147           2 :                           tdinfo->filtercond ? tdinfo->filtercond : "");
    2148             :     }
    2149             :     else
    2150             :     {
    2151        6298 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, "COPY %s %s TO stdout;",
    2152        6298 :                           fmtQualifiedDumpable(tbinfo),
    2153             :                           column_list);
    2154             :     }
    2155        6300 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, q->data, PGRES_COPY_OUT);
    2156        6298 :     PQclear(res);
    2157        6298 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(clistBuf);
    2158             : 
    2159             :     for (;;)
    2160             :     {
    2161     3424960 :         ret = PQgetCopyData(conn, &copybuf, 0);
    2162             : 
    2163     3424960 :         if (ret < 0)
    2164        6298 :             break;              /* done or error */
    2165             : 
    2166     3418662 :         if (copybuf)
    2167             :         {
    2168     3418662 :             WriteData(fout, copybuf, ret);
    2169     3418662 :             PQfreemem(copybuf);
    2170             :         }
    2171             : 
    2172             :         /* ----------
    2173             :          * THROTTLE:
    2174             :          *
    2175             :          * There was considerable discussion in late July, 2000 regarding
    2176             :          * slowing down pg_dump when backing up large tables. Users with both
    2177             :          * slow & fast (multi-processor) machines experienced performance
    2178             :          * degradation when doing a backup.
    2179             :          *
    2180             :          * Initial attempts based on sleeping for a number of ms for each ms
    2181             :          * of work were deemed too complex, then a simple 'sleep in each loop'
    2182             :          * implementation was suggested. The latter failed because the loop
    2183             :          * was too tight. Finally, the following was implemented:
    2184             :          *
    2185             :          * If throttle is non-zero, then
    2186             :          *      See how long since the last sleep.
    2187             :          *      Work out how long to sleep (based on ratio).
    2188             :          *      If sleep is more than 100ms, then
    2189             :          *          sleep
    2190             :          *          reset timer
    2191             :          *      EndIf
    2192             :          * EndIf
    2193             :          *
    2194             :          * where the throttle value was the number of ms to sleep per ms of
    2195             :          * work. The calculation was done in each loop.
    2196             :          *
    2197             :          * Most of the hard work is done in the backend, and this solution
    2198             :          * still did not work particularly well: on slow machines, the ratio
    2199             :          * was 50:1, and on medium paced machines, 1:1, and on fast
    2200             :          * multi-processor machines, it had little or no effect, for reasons
    2201             :          * that were unclear.
    2202             :          *
    2203             :          * Further discussion ensued, and the proposal was dropped.
    2204             :          *
    2205             :          * For those people who want this feature, it can be implemented using
    2206             :          * gettimeofday in each loop, calculating the time since last sleep,
    2207             :          * multiplying that by the sleep ratio, then if the result is more
    2208             :          * than a preset 'minimum sleep time' (say 100ms), call the 'select'
    2209             :          * function to sleep for a subsecond period ie.
    2210             :          *
    2211             :          * select(0, NULL, NULL, NULL, &tvi);
    2212             :          *
    2213             :          * This will return after the interval specified in the structure tvi.
    2214             :          * Finally, call gettimeofday again to save the 'last sleep time'.
    2215             :          * ----------
    2216             :          */
    2217             :     }
    2218        6298 :     archprintf(fout, "\\.\n\n\n");
    2219             : 
    2220        6298 :     if (ret == -2)
    2221             :     {
    2222             :         /* copy data transfer failed */
    2223           0 :         pg_log_error("Dumping the contents of table \"%s\" failed: PQgetCopyData() failed.", classname);
    2224           0 :         pg_log_error_detail("Error message from server: %s", PQerrorMessage(conn));
    2225           0 :         pg_log_error_detail("Command was: %s", q->data);
    2226           0 :         exit_nicely(1);
    2227             :     }
    2228             : 
    2229             :     /* Check command status and return to normal libpq state */
    2230        6298 :     res = PQgetResult(conn);
    2231        6298 :     if (PQresultStatus(res) != PGRES_COMMAND_OK)
    2232             :     {
    2233           0 :         pg_log_error("Dumping the contents of table \"%s\" failed: PQgetResult() failed.", classname);
    2234           0 :         pg_log_error_detail("Error message from server: %s", PQerrorMessage(conn));
    2235           0 :         pg_log_error_detail("Command was: %s", q->data);
    2236           0 :         exit_nicely(1);
    2237             :     }
    2238        6298 :     PQclear(res);
    2239             : 
    2240             :     /* Do this to ensure we've pumped libpq back to idle state */
    2241        6298 :     if (PQgetResult(conn) != NULL)
    2242           0 :         pg_log_warning("unexpected extra results during COPY of table \"%s\"",
    2243             :                        classname);
    2244             : 
    2245        6298 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(q);
    2246        6298 :     return 1;
    2247             : }
    2248             : 
    2249             : /*
    2250             :  * Dump table data using INSERT commands.
    2251             :  *
    2252             :  * Caution: when we restore from an archive file direct to database, the
    2253             :  * INSERT commands emitted by this function have to be parsed by
    2254             :  * pg_backup_db.c's ExecuteSimpleCommands(), which will not handle comments,
    2255             :  * E'' strings, or dollar-quoted strings.  So don't emit anything like that.
    2256             :  */
    2257             : static int
    2258         126 : dumpTableData_insert(Archive *fout, const void *dcontext)
    2259             : {
    2260         126 :     TableDataInfo *tdinfo = (TableDataInfo *) dcontext;
    2261         126 :     TableInfo  *tbinfo = tdinfo->tdtable;
    2262         126 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
    2263         126 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();

    2265             :     char       *attgenerated;
    2266             :     PGresult   *res;
    2267             :     int         nfields,
    2268             :                 i;
    2269         126 :     int         rows_per_statement = dopt->dump_inserts;
    2270         126 :     int         rows_this_statement = 0;
    2271             : 
    2272             :     /*
    2273             :      * If we're going to emit INSERTs with column names, the most efficient
    2274             :      * way to deal with generated columns is to exclude them entirely.  For
    2275             :      * INSERTs without column names, we have to emit DEFAULT rather than the
    2276             :      * actual column value --- but we can save a few cycles by fetching nulls
    2277             :      * rather than the uninteresting-to-us value.
    2278             :      */
    2279         126 :     attgenerated = (char *) pg_malloc(tbinfo->numatts * sizeof(char));
    2280         126 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "DECLARE _pg_dump_cursor CURSOR FOR SELECT ");
    2281         126 :     nfields = 0;
    2282         414 :     for (i = 0; i < tbinfo->numatts; i++)
    2283             :     {
    2284         288 :         if (tbinfo->attisdropped[i])
    2285           4 :             continue;
    2286         284 :         if (tbinfo->attgenerated[i] && dopt->column_inserts)
    2287          10 :             continue;
    2288         274 :         if (nfields > 0)
    2289         162 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
    2290         274 :         if (tbinfo->attgenerated[i])
    2291          10 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "NULL");
    2292             :         else
    2293         264 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, fmtId(tbinfo->attnames[i]));
    2294         274 :         attgenerated[nfields] = tbinfo->attgenerated[i];
    2295         274 :         nfields++;
    2296             :     }
    2297             :     /* Servers before 9.4 will complain about zero-column SELECT */

    2301         126 :                       fmtQualifiedDumpable(tbinfo));

    2303           0 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, " %s", tdinfo->filtercond);
    2304             :

    2306             : 
    2307             :     while (1)
    2308             :     {
    2309         226 :         res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, "FETCH 100 FROM _pg_dump_cursor",
    2310             :                               PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    2311             : 
    2312             :         /* cross-check field count, allowing for dummy NULL if any */
    2313         226 :         if (nfields != PQnfields(res) &&
    2314          20 :             !(nfields == 0 && PQnfields(res) == 1))
    2315           0 :             pg_fatal("wrong number of fields retrieved from table \"%s\"",
    2316             :                      tbinfo->dobj.name);
    2317             : 
    2318             :         /*
    2319             :          * First time through, we build as much of the INSERT statement as
    2320             :          * possible in "insertStmt", which we can then just print for each
    2321             :          * statement. If the table happens to have zero dumpable columns then

    2325         226 :         if (insertStmt == NULL)
    2326             :         {

    2328             :

    2330             :

    2355             :                 {
    2356          48 :                     appendPQExpBufferChar(insertStmt, '(');
    2357         162 :                     for (int field = 0; field < nfields; field++)

    2359         114 :                         if (field > 0)
    2360          66 :                             appendPQExpBufferStr(insertStmt, ", ");

    2362         114 :                                              fmtId(PQfname(res, field)));
    2363             :                     }
    2364          48 :                     appendPQExpBufferStr(insertStmt, ") ");
    2365             :                 }
    2366             : 
    2367         112 :                 if (tbinfo->needs_override)
    2368           4 :                     appendPQExpBufferStr(insertStmt, "OVERRIDING SYSTEM VALUE ");
    2369             : 
    2370         112 :                 appendPQExpBufferStr(insertStmt, "VALUES");
    2371             :             }
    2372             :         }
    2373             : 
    2374        6368 :         for (int tuple = 0; tuple < PQntuples(res); tuple++)
    2375             :         {
    2376             :             /* Write the INSERT if not in the middle of a multi-row INSERT. */
    2377        6142 :             if (rows_this_statement == 0)
    2378        6130 :                 archputs(insertStmt->data, fout);
    2379             : 
    2380             :             /*

    2382             :              * complete statement, which will mean we've disobeyed
    2383             :              * --rows-per-insert when it's set greater than 1.  We do support
    2384             :              * a way to make this multi-row with: SELECT UNION ALL SELECT
    2385             :              * UNION ALL ... but that's non-standard so we should avoid it
    2386             :              * given that using INSERTs is mostly only ever needed for
    2387             :              * cross-database exports.
    2388             :              */

    2390          12 :                 continue;
    2391             :

    2430             :                              * strtod() and friends might accept NaN, so we

    2649             :          * and want to order dump jobs by table size.  We choose to measure
    2650             :          * dataLength in table pages (including TOAST pages) during dump, so
    2651             :          * no scaling is needed.
    2652             :          *
    2653             :          * However, relpages is declared as "integer" in pg_class, and hence
    2654             :          * also in TableInfo, but it's really BlockNumber a/k/a unsigned int.
    2655             :          * Cast so that we get the right interpretation of table sizes
    2656             :          * exceeding INT_MAX pages.

    2658        6550 :         te->dataLength = (BlockNumber) tbinfo->relpages;
    2659        6550 :         te->dataLength += (BlockNumber) tbinfo->toastpages;

    2661             :         /*

    2663             :          * and instead we'd better worry about integer overflow.  Clamp to
    2664             :          * INT_MAX if the correct result exceeds that.
    2665             :          */
    2666             :         if (sizeof(te->dataLength) == 4 &&
    2667             :             (tbinfo->relpages < 0 || tbinfo->toastpages < 0 ||
    2668             :              te->dataLength < 0))

    2804             : /*
    2805             :  * The refresh for a materialized view must be dependent on the refresh for
    2806             :  * any materialized view that this one is dependent on.
    2807             :  *
    2808             :  * This must be called after all the objects are created, but before they are
    2809             :  * sorted.
    2810             :  */
    2811             : static void
    2812         262 : buildMatViewRefreshDependencies(Archive *fout)
    2813             : {
    2814             :     PQExpBuffer query;
    2815             :     PGresult   *res;
    2816             :     int         ntups,
    2817             :                 i;
    2818             :     int         i_classid,
    2819             :                 i_objid,
    2820             :                 i_refobjid;
    2821             : 
    2822             :     /* No Mat Views before 9.3. */
    2823         262 :     if (fout->remoteVersion < 90300)
    2824           0 :         return;
    2825             : 
    2826         262 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
    2827             : 
    2828         262 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "WITH RECURSIVE w AS "
    2829             :                          "( "
    2830             :                          "SELECT d1.objid, d2.refobjid, c2.relkind AS refrelkind "
    2831             :                          "FROM pg_depend d1 "
    2832             :                          "JOIN pg_class c1 ON c1.oid = d1.objid "
    2833             :                          "AND c1.relkind = " CppAsString2(RELKIND_MATVIEW)
    2834             :                          " JOIN pg_rewrite r1 ON r1.ev_class = d1.objid "
    2835             :                          "JOIN pg_depend d2 ON d2.classid = 'pg_rewrite'::regclass "
    2836             :                          "AND d2.objid = r1.oid "
    2837             :                          "AND d2.refobjid <> d1.objid "
    2838             :                          "JOIN pg_class c2 ON c2.oid = d2.refobjid "
    2839             :                          "AND c2.relkind IN (" CppAsString2(RELKIND_MATVIEW) ","
    2840             :                          CppAsString2(RELKIND_VIEW) ") "
    2841             :                          "WHERE d1.classid = 'pg_class'::regclass "
    2842             :                          "UNION "
    2843             :                          "SELECT w.objid, d3.refobjid, c3.relkind "
    2844             :                          "FROM w "
    2845             :                          "JOIN pg_rewrite r3 ON r3.ev_class = w.refobjid "
    2846             :                          "JOIN pg_depend d3 ON d3.classid = 'pg_rewrite'::regclass "
    2847             :                          "AND d3.objid = r3.oid "
    2848             :                          "AND d3.refobjid <> w.refobjid "
    2849             :                          "JOIN pg_class c3 ON c3.oid = d3.refobjid "
    2850             :                          "AND c3.relkind IN (" CppAsString2(RELKIND_MATVIEW) ","
    2851             :                          CppAsString2(RELKIND_VIEW) ") "
    2852             :                          ") "
    2853             :                          "SELECT 'pg_class'::regclass::oid AS classid, objid, refobjid "
    2854             :                          "FROM w "
    2855             :                          "WHERE refrelkind = " CppAsString2(RELKIND_MATVIEW));
    2856             : 
    2857         262 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    2858             : 
    2859         262 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
    2860             : 
    2861         262 :     i_classid = PQfnumber(res, "classid");
    2862         262 :     i_objid = PQfnumber(res, "objid");
    2863         262 :     i_refobjid = PQfnumber(res, "refobjid");
    2864             : 
    2865         742 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
    2866             :     {
    2867             :         CatalogId   objId;
    2868             :         CatalogId   refobjId;
    2869             :         DumpableObject *dobj;

    2911         262 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);

    2913             : 
    2914             : /*
    2915             :  * getTableDataFKConstraints -
    2916             :  *    add dump-order dependencies reflecting foreign key constraints
    2917             :  *
    2918             :  * This code is executed only in a data-only dump --- in schema+data dumps
    2919             :  * we handle foreign key issues by not creating the FK constraints until
    2920             :  * after the data is loaded.  In a data-only dump, however, we want to
    2921             :  * order the table data objects in such a way that a table's referenced
    2922             :  * tables are restored first.  (In the presence of circular references or
    2923             :  * self-references this may be impossible; we'll detect and complain about
    2924             :  * that during the dependency sorting step.)
    2925             :  */
    2926             : static void
    2927          12 : getTableDataFKConstraints(void)
    2928             : {
    2929             :     DumpableObject **dobjs;
    2930             :     int         numObjs;
    2931             :     int         i;
    2932             : 
    2933             :     /* Search through all the dumpable objects for FK constraints */
    2934          12 :     getDumpableObjects(&dobjs, &numObjs);
    2935       42622 :     for (i = 0; i < numObjs; i++)
    2936             :     {
    2937       42610 :         if (dobjs[i]->objType == DO_FK_CONSTRAINT)
    2938             :         {
    2939          12 :             ConstraintInfo *cinfo = (ConstraintInfo *) dobjs[i];
    2940             :             TableInfo  *ftable;
    2941             : 
    2942             :             /* Not interesting unless both tables are to be dumped */
    2943          12 :             if (cinfo->contable == NULL ||
    2944          12 :                 cinfo->contable->dataObj == NULL)
    2945           6 :                 continue;
    2946           6 :             ftable = findTableByOid(cinfo->confrelid);
    2947           6 :             if (ftable == NULL ||
    2948           6 :                 ftable->dataObj == NULL)
    2949           0 :                 continue;
    2950             : 
    2951             :             /*
    2952             :              * Okay, make referencing table's TABLE_DATA object depend on the
    2953             :              * referenced table's TABLE_DATA object.
    2954             :              */
    2955           6 :             addObjectDependency(&cinfo->contable->dataObj->dobj,
    2956           6 :                                 ftable->dataObj->dobj.dumpId);
    2957             :         }
    2958             :     }
    2959          12 :     free(dobjs);
    2960          12 : }
    2961             : 
    2962             :

    3271             :      * DATABASE in that context.)

    3519             : {
    3520         294 :     PQExpBuffer qry = createPQExpBuffer();

    3522             :     PGresult   *res;
    3523         294 :     char      **schemanames = NULL;
    3524         294 :     int         nschemanames = 0;

    3527             :     /*
    3528             :      * We use the result of current_schemas(), not the search_path GUC,
    3529             :      * because that might contain wildcards such as "$user", which won't
    3530             :      * necessarily have the same value during restore.  Also, this way avoids
    3531             :      * listing schemas that may appear in search_path but not actually exist,
    3532             :      * which seems like a prudent exclusion.
    3533             :      */
    3534         294 :     res = ExecuteSqlQueryForSingleRow(AH,

    3543             :      * that's likely to get fixed at some point, it seems like a good idea to
    3544             :      * be as backwards-compatible as possible in what we put into archives.
    3545             :      */
    3546         294 :     for (i = 0; i < nschemanames; i++)
    3547             :     {

    3716             : /*
    3717             :  * dumpLOs:
    3718             :  *  dump the data contents of all large objects
    3719             :  */
    3720             : static int
    3721          64 : dumpLOs(Archive *fout, const void *arg)
    3722             : {
    3723             :     const char *loQry;
    3724             :     const char *loFetchQry;
    3725          64 :     PGconn     *conn = GetConnection(fout);
    3726             :     PGresult   *res;
    3727             :     char        buf[LOBBUFSIZE];
    3728             :     int         ntups;
    3729             :     int         i;
    3730             :     int         cnt;
    3731             : 
    3732          64 :     pg_log_info("saving large objects");
    3733             : 
    3734             :     /*
    3735             :      * Currently, we re-fetch all LO OIDs using a cursor.  Consider scanning
    3736             :      * the already-in-memory dumpable objects instead...
    3737             :      */
    3738          64 :     loQry =
    3739             :         "DECLARE looid CURSOR FOR "
    3740             :         "SELECT oid FROM pg_largeobject_metadata ORDER BY 1";
    3741             : 
    3742          64 :     ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, loQry);
    3743             : 
    3744             :     /* Command to fetch from cursor */
    3745          64 :     loFetchQry = "FETCH 1000 IN looid";
    3746             : 
    3747             :     do
    3748             :     {
    3749             :         /* Do a fetch */
    3750         128 :         res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, loFetchQry, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    3751             : 
    3752             :         /* Process the tuples, if any */
    3753         128 :         ntups = PQntuples(res);
    3754         264 :         for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
    3755             :         {
    3756             :             Oid         loOid;
    3757             :             int         loFd;
    3758             : 
    3759         136 :             loOid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, 0));
    3760             :             /* Open the LO */
    3761         136 :             loFd = lo_open(conn, loOid, INV_READ);
    3762         136 :             if (loFd == -1)
    3763           0 :                 pg_fatal("could not open large object %u: %s",
    3764             :                          loOid, PQerrorMessage(conn));
    3765             : 
    3766         136 :             StartLO(fout, loOid);
    3767             : 
    3768             :             /* Now read it in chunks, sending data to archive */
    3769             :             do
    3770             :             {
    3771         208 :                 cnt = lo_read(conn, loFd, buf, LOBBUFSIZE);
    3772         208 :                 if (cnt < 0)
    3773           0 :                     pg_fatal("error reading large object %u: %s",
    3774             :                              loOid, PQerrorMessage(conn));
    3775             : 
    3776         208 :                 WriteData(fout, buf, cnt);
    3777         208 :             } while (cnt > 0);

    3779         136 :             lo_close(conn, loFd);
    3780             : 
    3781         136 :             EndLO(fout, loOid);
    3782             :         }

    3785         128 :     } while (ntups > 0);
    3786             : 
    3787          64 :     return 1;

    3790             : /*
    3791             :  * getPolicies
    3792             :  *    get information about all RLS policies on dumpable tables.
    3793             :  */
    3794             : void
    3795         294 : getPolicies(Archive *fout, TableInfo tblinfo[], int numTables)
    3796             : {
    3797             :     PQExpBuffer query;
    3798             :     PQExpBuffer tbloids;

    3963             : {

    4179             : /*
    4180             :  * dumpPublication

    4183             : static void

    5169             : 
    5170             : static Oid
    5171           0 : get_next_possible_free_pg_type_oid(Archive *fout, PQExpBuffer upgrade_query)
    5172             : {
    5173             :     /*
    5174             :      * If the old version didn't assign an array type, but the new version
    5175             :      * does, we must select an unused type OID to assign.  This currently only
    5176             :      * happens for domains, when upgrading pre-v11 to v11 and up.
    5177             :      *
    5178             :      * Note: local state here is kind of ugly, but we must have some, since we
    5179             :      * mustn't choose the same unused OID more than once.
    5180             :      */
    5181             :     static Oid  next_possible_free_oid = FirstNormalObjectId;
    5182             :     PGresult   *res;
    5183             :     bool        is_dup;
    5184             : 
    5185             :     do
    5186             :     {
    5187           0 :         ++next_possible_free_oid;
    5188           0 :         printfPQExpBuffer(upgrade_query,
    5189             :                           "SELECT EXISTS(SELECT 1 "
    5190             :                           "FROM pg_catalog.pg_type "
    5191             :                           "WHERE oid = '%u'::pg_catalog.oid);",
    5192             :                           next_possible_free_oid);

    5298             : static void
    5299        2164 : binary_upgrade_set_pg_class_oids(Archive *fout,
    5300             :                                  PQExpBuffer upgrade_buffer, Oid pg_class_oid,
    5301             :                                  bool is_index)
    5302             : {
    5303        2164 :     PQExpBuffer upgrade_query = createPQExpBuffer();
    5304             :     PGresult   *upgrade_res;
    5305             :     RelFileNumber relfilenumber;
    5306             :     Oid         toast_oid;

    5309             :     Oid         toast_index_oid;
    5310             :     RelFileNumber toast_index_relfilenumber;
    5311             : 
    5312             :     /*
    5313             :      * Preserve the OID and relfilenumber of the table, table's index, table's
    5314             :      * toast table and toast table's index if any.
    5315             :      *
    5316             :      * One complexity is that the current table definition might not require
    5317             :      * the creation of a TOAST table, but the old database might have a TOAST
    5318             :      * table that was created earlier, before some wide columns were dropped.
    5319             :      * By setting the TOAST oid we force creation of the TOAST heap and index
    5320             :      * by the new backend, so we can copy the files during binary upgrade
    5321             :      * without worrying about this case.
    5322             :      */
    5323        2164 :     appendPQExpBuffer(upgrade_query,
    5324             :                       "SELECT c.relkind, c.relfilenode, c.reltoastrelid, ct.relfilenode AS toast_relfilenode, i.indexrelid, cti.relfilenode AS toast_index_relfilenode "

    5326             :                       "pg_catalog.pg_index i ON (c.reltoastrelid = i.indrelid AND i.indisvalid) "
    5327             :                       "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_class ct ON (c.reltoastrelid = ct.oid) "
    5328             :                       "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_class AS cti ON (i.indexrelid = cti.oid) "

    5431             :      * direct dependency on their own extension, not any others.

    5454             : /*
    5455             :  * getNamespaces:
    5456             :  *    read all namespaces in the system catalogs and return them in the

    5458             :  *
    5459             :  *  numNamespaces is set to the number of namespaces read in
    5460             :  */
    5461             : NamespaceInfo *
    5462         296 : getNamespaces(Archive *fout, int *numNamespaces)
    5463             : {
    5464             :     PGresult   *res;
    5465             :     int         ntups;

    5467             :     PQExpBuffer query;
    5468             :     NamespaceInfo *nsinfo;
    5469             :     int         i_tableoid;
    5470             :     int         i_oid;

    5472             :     int         i_nspowner;
    5473             :     int         i_nspacl;
    5474             :     int         i_acldefault;
    5475             : 
    5476         296 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
    5477             : 
    5478             :     /*
    5479             :      * we fetch all namespaces including system ones, so that every object we
    5480             :      * read in can be linked to a containing namespace.
    5481             :      */
    5482         296 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT n.tableoid, n.oid, n.nspname, "
    5483             :                          "n.nspowner, "
    5484             :                          "n.nspacl, "
    5485             :                          "acldefault('n', n.nspowner) AS acldefault "
    5486             :                          "FROM pg_namespace n");
    5487             : 
    5488         296 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    5489             : 
    5490         296 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
    5491             : 
    5492         296 :     nsinfo = (NamespaceInfo *) pg_malloc(ntups * sizeof(NamespaceInfo));
    5493             : 
    5494         296 :     i_tableoid = PQfnumber(res, "tableoid");

    5500             : 
    5501        2084 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
    5502             :     {
    5503             :         const char *nspowner;
    5504             : 
    5505        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dobj.objType = DO_NAMESPACE;
    5506        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dobj.catId.tableoid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_tableoid));
    5507        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dobj.catId.oid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_oid));
    5508        1788 :         AssignDumpId(&nsinfo[i].dobj);
    5509        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dobj.name = pg_strdup(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_nspname));
    5510        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dacl.acl = pg_strdup(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_nspacl));
    5511        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dacl.acldefault = pg_strdup(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_acldefault));
    5512        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dacl.privtype = 0;
    5513        1788 :         nsinfo[i].dacl.initprivs = NULL;
    5514        1788 :         nspowner = PQgetvalue(res, i, i_nspowner);
    5515        1788 :         nsinfo[i].nspowner = atooid(nspowner);
    5516        1788 :         nsinfo[i].rolname = getRoleName(nspowner);
    5517             : 
    5518             :         /* Decide whether to dump this namespace */
    5519        1788 :         selectDumpableNamespace(&nsinfo[i], fout);
    5520             : 
    5521             :         /* Mark whether namespace has an ACL */
    5522        1788 :         if (!PQgetisnull(res, i, i_nspacl))
    5523         970 :             nsinfo[i].dobj.components |= DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL;
    5524             : 
    5525             :         /*
    5526             :          * We ignore any pg_init_privs.initprivs entry for the public schema
    5527             :          * and assume a predetermined default, for several reasons.  First,
    5528             :          * dropping and recreating the schema removes its pg_init_privs entry,
    5529             :          * but an empty destination database starts with this ACL nonetheless.
    5530             :          * Second, we support dump/reload of public schema ownership changes.
    5531             :          * ALTER SCHEMA OWNER filters nspacl through aclnewowner(), but
    5532             :          * initprivs continues to reflect the initial owner.  Hence,
    5533             :          * synthesize the value that nspacl will have after the restore's
    5534             :          * ALTER SCHEMA OWNER.  Third, this makes the destination database
    5535             :          * match the source's ACL, even if the latter was an initdb-default
    5536             :          * ACL, which changed in v15.  An upgrade pulls in changes to most
    5537             :          * system object ACLs that the DBA had not customized.  We've made the
    5538             :          * public schema depart from that, because changing its ACL so easily
    5539             :          * breaks applications.
    5540             :          */
    5541        1788 :         if (strcmp(nsinfo[i].dobj.name, "public") == 0)
    5542             :         {
    5543         288 :             PQExpBuffer aclarray = createPQExpBuffer();
    5544         288 :             PQExpBuffer aclitem = createPQExpBuffer();
    5545             : 
    5546             :             /* Standard ACL as of v15 is {owner=UC/owner,=U/owner} */
    5547         288 :             appendPQExpBufferChar(aclarray, '{');
    5548         288 :             quoteAclUserName(aclitem, nsinfo[i].rolname);
    5549         288 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(aclitem, "=UC/");
    5550         288 :             quoteAclUserName(aclitem, nsinfo[i].rolname);
    5551         288 :             appendPGArray(aclarray, aclitem->data);
    5552         288 :             resetPQExpBuffer(aclitem);
    5553         288 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(aclitem, "=U/");
    5554         288 :             quoteAclUserName(aclitem, nsinfo[i].rolname);
    5555         288 :             appendPGArray(aclarray, aclitem->data);
    5556         288 :             appendPQExpBufferChar(aclarray, '}');
    5557             : 
    5558         288 :             nsinfo[i].dacl.privtype = 'i';
    5559         288 :             nsinfo[i].dacl.initprivs = pstrdup(aclarray->data);
    5560         288 :             nsinfo[i].dobj.components |= DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL;
    5561             : 
    5562         288 :             destroyPQExpBuffer(aclarray);
    5563         288 :             destroyPQExpBuffer(aclitem);
    5564             :         }
    5565             :     }
    5566             : 
    5567         296 :     PQclear(res);
    5568         296 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
    5569             :

    5571             :

    5590             : /*
    5591             :  * getExtensions:

    5597             : ExtensionInfo *
    5598         296 : getExtensions(Archive *fout, int *numExtensions)
    5599             : {

    5614             : 
    5615         296 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
    5616             : 
    5617         296 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT x.tableoid, x.oid, "
    5618             :                          "x.extname, n.nspname, x.extrelocatable, x.extversion, x.extconfig, x.extcondition "
    5619             :                          "FROM pg_extension x "
    5620             :                          "JOIN pg_namespace n ON n.oid = x.extnamespace");
    5621             : 
    5622         296 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    5623             : 
    5624         296 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
    5625             : 
    5626         296 :     extinfo = (ExtensionInfo *) pg_malloc(ntups * sizeof(ExtensionInfo));
    5627             :

    5662             : /*
    5663             :  * getTypes:
    5664             :  *    read all types in the system catalogs and return them in the

    5666             :  *
    5667             :  *  numTypes is set to the number of types read in

    5673         294 : getTypes(Archive *fout, int *numTypes)
    5674             : {
    5675             :     PGresult   *res;
    5676             :     int         ntups;

    5678         294 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();

    5681             :     int         i_tableoid;
    5682             :     int         i_oid;

    5686             :     int         i_acldefault;

    5689             :     int         i_typrelid;
    5690             :     int         i_typrelkind;
    5691             :     int         i_typtype;
    5692             :     int         i_typisdefined;
    5693             :     int         i_isarray;
    5694             : 
    5695             :     /*
    5696             :      * we include even the built-in types because those may be used as array
    5697             :      * elements by user-defined types
    5698             :      *
    5699             :      * we filter out the built-in types when we dump out the types
    5700             :      *
    5701             :      * same approach for undefined (shell) types and array types
    5702             :      *
    5703             :      * Note: as of 8.3 we can reliably detect whether a type is an
    5704             :      * auto-generated array type by checking the element type's typarray.
    5705             :      * (Before that the test is capable of generating false positives.) We
    5706             :      * still check for name beginning with '_', though, so as to avoid the
    5707             :      * cost of the subselect probe for all standard types.  This would have to
    5708             :      * be revisited if the backend ever allows renaming of array types.
    5709             :      */
    5710         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT tableoid, oid, typname, "
    5711             :                          "typnamespace, typacl, "
    5712             :                          "acldefault('T', typowner) AS acldefault, "

    5714             :                          "typelem, typrelid, "

    6396             : 
    6397             : /*
    6398             :  * getFuncs:
    6399             :  *    read all the user-defined functions in the system catalogs and
    6400             :  * return them in the FuncInfo* structure
    6401             :  *
    6402             :  * numFuncs is set to the number of functions read in
    6403             :  */
    6404             : FuncInfo *
    6405         294 : getFuncs(Archive *fout, int *numFuncs)
    6406             : {
    6407         294 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
    6408             :     PGresult   *res;
    6409             :     int         ntups;
    6410             :     int         i;
    6411         294 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
    6412             :     FuncInfo   *finfo;
    6413             :     int         i_tableoid;
    6414             :     int         i_oid;
    6415             :     int         i_proname;
    6416             :     int         i_pronamespace;
    6417             :     int         i_proowner;
    6418             :     int         i_prolang;
    6419             :     int         i_pronargs;
    6420             :     int         i_proargtypes;
    6421             :     int         i_prorettype;
    6422             :     int         i_proacl;
    6423             :     int         i_acldefault;
    6424             : 
    6425             :     /*
    6426             :      * Find all interesting functions.  This is a bit complicated:
    6427             :      *
    6428             :      * 1. Always exclude aggregates; those are handled elsewhere.
    6429             :      *
    6430             :      * 2. Always exclude functions that are internally dependent on something
    6431             :      * else, since presumably those will be created as a result of creating
    6432             :      * the something else.  This currently acts only to suppress constructor
    6433             :      * functions for range types.  Note this is OK only because the
    6434             :      * constructors don't have any dependencies the range type doesn't have;
    6435             :      * otherwise we might not get creation ordering correct.
    6436             :      *
    6437             :      * 3. Otherwise, we normally exclude functions in pg_catalog.  However, if
    6438             :      * they're members of extensions and we are in binary-upgrade mode then
    6439             :      * include them, since we want to dump extension members individually in
    6440             :      * that mode.  Also, if they are used by casts or transforms then we need
    6441             :      * to gather the information about them, though they won't be dumped if
    6442             :      * they are built-in.  Also, in 9.6 and up, include functions in
    6443             :      * pg_catalog if they have an ACL different from what's shown in
    6444             :      * pg_init_privs (so we have to join to pg_init_privs; annoying).
    6445             :      */
    6446         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 90600)
    6447             :     {
    6448             :         const char *not_agg_check;
    6449             : 
    6450         588 :         not_agg_check = (fout->remoteVersion >= 110000 ? "p.prokind <> 'a'"
    6451         294 :                          : "NOT p.proisagg");
    6452             : 
    6453         294 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    6454             :                           "SELECT p.tableoid, p.oid, p.proname, p.prolang, "
    6455             :                           "p.pronargs, p.proargtypes, p.prorettype, "
    6456             :                           "p.proacl, "
    6457             :                           "acldefault('f', p.proowner) AS acldefault, "
    6458             :                           "p.pronamespace, "
    6459             :                           "p.proowner "
    6460             :                           "FROM pg_proc p "
    6461             :                           "LEFT JOIN pg_init_privs pip ON "
    6462             :                           "(p.oid = pip.objoid "
    6463             :                           "AND pip.classoid = 'pg_proc'::regclass "
    6464             :                           "AND pip.objsubid = 0) "
    6465             :                           "WHERE %s"
    6466             :                           "\n  AND NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_depend "
    6467             :                           "WHERE classid = 'pg_proc'::regclass AND "
    6468             :                           "objid = p.oid AND deptype = 'i')"
    6469             :                           "\n  AND ("
    6470             :                           "\n  pronamespace != "
    6471             :                           "(SELECT oid FROM pg_namespace "
    6472             :                           "WHERE nspname = 'pg_catalog')"
    6473             :                           "\n  OR EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_cast"
    6474             :                           "\n  WHERE pg_cast.oid > %u "
    6475             :                           "\n  AND p.oid = pg_cast.castfunc)"
    6476             :                           "\n  OR EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_transform"
    6477             :                           "\n  WHERE pg_transform.oid > %u AND "
    6478             :                           "\n  (p.oid = pg_transform.trffromsql"
    6479             :                           "\n  OR p.oid = pg_transform.trftosql))",
    6480             :                           not_agg_check,
    6481             :                           g_last_builtin_oid,
    6482             :                           g_last_builtin_oid);
    6483         294 :         if (dopt->binary_upgrade)
    6484          28 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    6485             :                                  "\n  OR EXISTS(SELECT 1 FROM pg_depend WHERE "
    6486             :                                  "classid = 'pg_proc'::regclass AND "
    6487             :                                  "objid = p.oid AND "
    6488             :                                  "refclassid = 'pg_extension'::regclass AND "
    6489             :                                  "deptype = 'e')");
    6490         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    6491             :                              "\n  OR p.proacl IS DISTINCT FROM pip.initprivs");
    6492         294 :         appendPQExpBufferChar(query, ')');
    6493             :     }
    6494             :     else
    6495             :     {
    6496           0 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    6497             :                           "SELECT tableoid, oid, proname, prolang, "
    6498             :                           "pronargs, proargtypes, prorettype, proacl, "
    6499             :                           "acldefault('f', proowner) AS acldefault, "
    6500             :                           "pronamespace, "
    6501             :                           "proowner "
    6502             :                           "FROM pg_proc p "
    6503             :                           "WHERE NOT proisagg"
    6504             :                           "\n  AND NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_depend "
    6505             :                           "WHERE classid = 'pg_proc'::regclass AND "
    6506             :                           "objid = p.oid AND deptype = 'i')"
    6507             :                           "\n  AND ("
    6508             :                           "\n  pronamespace != "
    6509             :                           "(SELECT oid FROM pg_namespace "
    6510             :                           "WHERE nspname = 'pg_catalog')"
    6511             :                           "\n  OR EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_cast"
    6512             :                           "\n  WHERE pg_cast.oid > '%u'::oid"
    6513             :                           "\n  AND p.oid = pg_cast.castfunc)",
    6514             :                           g_last_builtin_oid);
    6515             : 
    6516           0 :         if (fout->remoteVersion >= 90500)
    6517           0 :             appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    6518             :                               "\n  OR EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM pg_transform"
    6519             :                               "\n  WHERE pg_transform.oid > '%u'::oid"
    6520             :                               "\n  AND (p.oid = pg_transform.trffromsql"
    6521             :                               "\n  OR p.oid = pg_transform.trftosql))",

    6595             : 
    6596             : /*
    6597             :  * getTables
    6598             :  *    read all the tables (no indexes) in the system catalogs,
    6599             :  *    and return them as an array of TableInfo structures
    6600             :  *
    6601             :  * *numTables is set to the number of tables read in
    6602             :  */
    6603             : TableInfo *
    6604         296 : getTables(Archive *fout, int *numTables)
    6605             : {
    6606         296 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;

    6647             :     int         i_acldefault;

    6649             : 
    6650             :     /*
    6651             :      * Find all the tables and table-like objects.
    6652             :      *
    6653             :      * We must fetch all tables in this phase because otherwise we cannot
    6654             :      * correctly identify inherited columns, owned sequences, etc.
    6655             :      *
    6656             :      * We include system catalogs, so that we can work if a user table is
    6657             :      * defined to inherit from a system catalog (pretty weird, but...)
    6658             :      *
    6659             :      * Note: in this phase we should collect only a minimal amount of
    6660             :      * information about each table, basically just enough to decide if it is
    6661             :      * interesting.  In particular, since we do not yet have lock on any user
    6662             :      * table, we MUST NOT invoke any server-side data collection functions
    6663             :      * (for instance, pg_get_partkeydef()).  Those are likely to fail or give
    6664             :      * wrong answers if any concurrent DDL is happening.
    6665             :      */
    6666             : 
    6667         296 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    6668             :                          "SELECT c.tableoid, c.oid, c.relname, "
    6669             :                          "c.relnamespace, c.relkind, c.reltype, "
    6670             :                          "c.relowner, "
    6671             :                          "c.relchecks, "
    6672             :                          "c.relhasindex, c.relhasrules, c.relpages, "
    6673             :                          "c.relhastriggers, "
    6674             :                          "c.relpersistence, "

    6756             :     /*
    6757             :      * Left join to pg_depend to pick up dependency info linking sequences to

    6778             :     /*
    6779             :      * We purposefully ignore toast OIDs for partitioned tables; the reason is

    6781             :      * emitting them causes the upgrade to fail.

    6788             :     /*

    6790             :      * relkinds are possible in older servers, but it's not worth the trouble
    6791             :      * to emit a version-dependent list.

    6794             :      * make a DumpableObject for them so that we can track dependencies of the

    6815             :     /*
    6816             :      * Extract data from result and lock dumpable tables.  We do the locking

    6818             :      * disappear under us.
    6819             :      *
    6820             :      * Note that we have to save info about all tables here, even when dumping

    6921       74436 :         tblinfo[i].rowsec = (strcmp(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_relrowsec), "t") == 0);

    6941       74436 :         tblinfo[i].ispartition = (strcmp(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_ispartition), "t") == 0);
    6942             : 
    6943             :         /* other fields were zeroed above */
    6944             : 
    6945             :         /*
    6946             :          * Decide whether we want to dump this table.
    6947             :          */
    6948       74436 :         if (tblinfo[i].relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)
    6949         268 :             tblinfo[i].dobj.dump = DUMP_COMPONENT_NONE;
    6950             :         else
    6951       74168 :             selectDumpableTable(&tblinfo[i], fout);
    6952             : 
    6953             :         /*
    6954             :          * Now, consider the table "interesting" if we need to dump its
    6955             :          * definition or its data.  Later on, we'll skip a lot of data
    6956             :          * collection for uninteresting tables.
    6957             :          *
    6958             :          * Note: the "interesting" flag will also be set by flagInhTables for
    6959             :          * parents of interesting tables, so that we collect necessary
    6960             :          * inheritance info even when the parents are not themselves being
    6961             :          * dumped.  This is the main reason why we need an "interesting" flag
    6962             :          * that's separate from the components-to-dump bitmask.
    6963             :          */
    6964       74436 :         tblinfo[i].interesting = (tblinfo[i].dobj.dump &
    6965             :                                   (DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION |
    6966       74436 :                                    DUMP_COMPONENT_DATA)) != 0;
    6967             : 
    6968       74436 :         tblinfo[i].dummy_view = false;  /* might get set during sort */
    6969       74436 :         tblinfo[i].postponed_def = false;   /* might get set during sort */
    6970             : 
    6971             :         /* Tables have data */
    6972       74436 :         tblinfo[i].dobj.components |= DUMP_COMPONENT_DATA;
    6973             : 
    6974             :         /* Mark whether table has an ACL */
    6975       74436 :         if (!PQgetisnull(res, i, i_relacl))
    6976       61384 :             tblinfo[i].dobj.components |= DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL;
    6977       74436 :         tblinfo[i].hascolumnACLs = false;   /* may get set later */
    6978             : 
    6979             :         /*
    6980             :          * Read-lock target tables to make sure they aren't DROPPED or altered
    6981             :          * in schema before we get around to dumping them.
    6982             :          *
    6983             :          * Note that we don't explicitly lock parents of the target tables; we
    6984             :          * assume our lock on the child is enough to prevent schema
    6985             :          * alterations to parent tables.
    6986             :          *
    6987             :          * NOTE: it'd be kinda nice to lock other relations too, not only
    6988             :          * plain or partitioned tables, but the backend doesn't presently
    6989             :          * allow that.
    6990             :          *
    6991             :          * We only need to lock the table for certain components; see
    6992             :          * pg_dump.h
    6993             :          */
    6994       74436 :         if ((tblinfo[i].dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENTS_REQUIRING_LOCK) &&
    6995       10870 :             (tblinfo[i].relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
    6996        3036 :              tblinfo[i].relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE))
    6997             :         {
    6998             :             /*
    6999             :              * Tables are locked in batches.  When dumping from a remote
    7000             :              * server this can save a significant amount of time by reducing
    7001             :              * the number of round trips.
    7002             :              */
    7003        8768 :             if (query->len == 0)
    7004         184 :                 appendPQExpBuffer(query, "LOCK TABLE %s",
    7005         184 :                                   fmtQualifiedDumpable(&tblinfo[i]));
    7006             :             else
    7007             :             {
    7008        8584 :                 appendPQExpBuffer(query, ", %s",
    7009        8584 :                                   fmtQualifiedDumpable(&tblinfo[i]));
    7010             : 
    7011             :                 /* Arbitrarily end a batch when query length reaches 100K. */
    7012        8584 :                 if (query->len >= 100000)
    7013             :                 {
    7014             :                     /* Lock another batch of tables. */
    7015           0 :                     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, " IN ACCESS SHARE MODE");
    7016           0 :                     ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, query->data);
    7017           0 :                     resetPQExpBuffer(query);
    7018             :                 }
    7019             :             }
    7020             :         }
    7021             :     }
    7022             : 
    7023         296 :     if (query->len != 0)
    7024             :     {
    7025             :         /* Lock the tables in the last batch. */
    7026         184 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query, " IN ACCESS SHARE MODE");
    7027         184 :         ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, query->data);
    7028             :     }
    7029             : 
    7030         294 :     if (dopt->lockWaitTimeout)
    7031             :     {

    7033             :     }
    7034             : 
    7035         294 :     PQclear(res);
    7036             :

    7042             : /*
    7043             :  * getOwnedSeqs
    7044             :  *    identify owned sequences and mark them as dumpable if owning table is
    7045             :  *
    7046             :  * We used to do this in getTables(), but it's better to do it after the
    7047             :  * index used by findTableByOid() has been set up.

    7049             : void
    7050         294 : getOwnedSeqs(Archive *fout, TableInfo tblinfo[], int numTables)
    7051             : {
    7052             :     int         i;
    7053             : 
    7054             :     /*
    7055             :      * Force sequences that are "owned" by table columns to be dumped whenever
    7056             :      * their owning table is being dumped.
    7057             :      */

    7059             :     {

    7062             :

    7064       73312 :             continue;           /* not an owned sequence */

    7066         616 :         owning_tab = findTableByOid(seqinfo->owning_tab);
    7067         616 :         if (owning_tab == NULL)
    7068           0 :             pg_fatal("failed sanity check, parent table with OID %u of sequence with OID %u not found",

    7070             : 
    7071             :         /*

    7073             :          * it belongs to.
    7074             :          */
    7075         616 :         if (owning_tab->dobj.dump == DUMP_COMPONENT_NONE &&
    7076          48 :             seqinfo->is_identity_sequence)
    7077             :         {

    7079          14 :             continue;
    7080             :         }
    7081             : 
    7082             :         /*
    7083             :          * Otherwise we need to dump the components that are being dumped for
    7084             :          * the table and any components which the sequence is explicitly
    7085             :          * marked with.
    7086             :          *
    7087             :          * We can't simply use the set of components which are being dumped
    7088             :          * for the table as the table might be in an extension (and only the
    7089             :          * non-extension components, eg: ACLs if changed, security labels, and
    7090             :          * policies, are being dumped) while the sequence is not (and
    7091             :          * therefore the definition and other components should also be
    7092             :          * dumped).
    7093             :          *

    7095             :          * marked by checkExtensionMembership() and this will be a no-op as
    7096             :          * the table will be equivalently marked.
    7097             :          */
    7098         602 :         seqinfo->dobj.dump = seqinfo->dobj.dump | owning_tab->dobj.dump;

    7102             :     }
