    7151             : /*
    7152             :  * getPartitioningInfo
    7153             :  *    get information about partitioning
    7154             :  *
    7155             :  * For the most part, we only collect partitioning info about tables we
    7156             :  * intend to dump.  However, this function has to consider all partitioned
    7157             :  * tables in the database, because we need to know about parents of partitions
    7158             :  * we are going to dump even if the parents themselves won't be dumped.
    7159             :  *
    7160             :  * Specifically, what we need to know is whether each partitioned table
    7161             :  * has an "unsafe" partitioning scheme that requires us to force
    7162             :  * load-via-partition-root mode for its children.  Currently the only case
    7163             :  * for which we force that is hash partitioning on enum columns, since the
    7164             :  * hash codes depend on enum value OIDs which won't be replicated across
    7165             :  * dump-and-reload.  There are other cases in which load-via-partition-root
    7166             :  * might be necessary, but we expect users to cope with them.
    7167             :  */
    7168             : void
    7169         294 : getPartitioningInfo(Archive *fout)
    7170             : {
    7171             :     PQExpBuffer query;
    7172             :     PGresult   *res;
    7173             :     int         ntups;
    7174             : 
    7175             :     /* hash partitioning didn't exist before v11 */
    7176         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion < 110000)
    7177           0 :         return;
    7178             :     /* needn't bother if schema-only dump */
    7179         294 :     if (fout->dopt->schemaOnly)
    7180          32 :         return;
    7181             : 
    7182         262 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
    7183             : 
    7184             :     /*
    7185             :      * Unsafe partitioning schemes are exactly those for which hash enum_ops
    7186             :      * appears among the partition opclasses.  We needn't check partstrat.
    7187             :      *
    7188             :      * Note that this query may well retrieve info about tables we aren't
    7189             :      * going to dump and hence have no lock on.  That's okay since we need not
    7190             :      * invoke any unsafe server-side functions.
    7191             :      */
    7192         262 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    7193             :                          "SELECT partrelid FROM pg_partitioned_table WHERE\n"
    7194             :                          "(SELECT c.oid FROM pg_opclass c JOIN pg_am a "
    7195             :                          "ON c.opcmethod = a.oid\n"
    7196             :                          "WHERE opcname = 'enum_ops' "
    7197             :                          "AND opcnamespace = 'pg_catalog'::regnamespace "
    7198             :                          "AND amname = 'hash') = ANY(partclass)");
    7199             : 
    7200         262 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    7201             : 
    7202         262 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
    7203             : 
    7204         266 :     for (int i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
    7205             :     {
    7206           4 :         Oid         tabrelid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, 0));
    7207             :         TableInfo  *tbinfo;
    7208             : 
    7209           4 :         tbinfo = findTableByOid(tabrelid);

    7211           0 :             pg_fatal("failed sanity check, table OID %u appearing in pg_partitioned_table not found",

    7213           4 :         tbinfo->unsafe_partitions = true;
    7214             :     }
    7215             : 
    7216         262 :     PQclear(res);
    7217             :

    7221             : /*
    7222             :  * getIndexes

    7226             :  * does get entered into the DumpableObject tables.

    7228             : void
    7229         294 : getIndexes(Archive *fout, TableInfo tblinfo[], int numTables)
    7230             : {
    7231         294 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();

    7233             :     PGresult   *res;
    7234             :     int         ntups;
    7235             :     int         curtblindx;
    7236             :     IndxInfo   *indxinfo;

    7238             :                 i_oid,

    7241             :                 i_parentidx,

    7243             :                 i_indnkeyatts,
    7244             :                 i_indnatts,
    7245             :                 i_indkey,
    7246             :                 i_indisclustered,
    7247             :                 i_indisreplident,
    7248             :                 i_indnullsnotdistinct,
    7249             :                 i_contype,
    7250             :                 i_conname,
    7251             :                 i_condeferrable,
    7252             :                 i_condeferred,
    7253             :                 i_conwithoutoverlaps,
    7254             :                 i_contableoid,
    7255             :                 i_conoid,
    7256             :                 i_condef,

    7258             :                 i_indreloptions,
    7259             :                 i_indstatcols,
    7260             :                 i_indstatvals;
    7261             : 
    7262             :     /*
    7263             :      * We want to perform just one query against pg_index.  However, we
    7264             :      * mustn't try to select every row of the catalog and then sort it out on
    7265             :      * the client side, because some of the server-side functions we need
    7266             :      * would be unsafe to apply to tables we don't have lock on.  Hence, we
    7267             :      * build an array of the OIDs of tables we care about (and now have lock
    7268             :      * on!), and use a WHERE clause to constrain which rows are selected.
    7269             :      */
    7270         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '{');
    7271       74222 :     for (int i = 0; i < numTables; i++)

    7279             :          * We can ignore indexes of uninteresting tables.

    7335             :                              "i.indnullsnotdistinct, ");
    7336             :     else
    7337           0 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    7338             :                              "false AS indnullsnotdistinct, ");
    7339             : 
    7340         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 170000)
    7341         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    7342             :                              "c.conwithoutoverlaps ");
    7343             :     else
    7344           0 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    7345             :                              "NULL AS conwithoutoverlaps ");
    7346             : 
    7347             :     /*
    7348             :      * The point of the messy-looking outer join is to find a constraint that
    7349             :      * is related by an internal dependency link to the index. If we find one,
    7350             :      * create a CONSTRAINT entry linked to the INDEX entry.  We assume an
    7351             :      * index won't have more than one internal dependency.
    7352             :      *
    7353             :      * Note: the check on conrelid is redundant, but useful because that
    7354             :      * column is indexed while conindid is not.
    7355             :      */
    7356         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 110000)
    7357             :     {
    7358         294 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    7359             :                           "FROM unnest('%s'::pg_catalog.oid[]) AS src(tbloid)\n"
    7360             :                           "JOIN pg_catalog.pg_index i ON (src.tbloid = i.indrelid) "
    7361             :                           "JOIN pg_catalog.pg_class t ON (t.oid = i.indexrelid) "
    7362             :                           "JOIN pg_catalog.pg_class t2 ON (t2.oid = i.indrelid) "
    7363             :                           "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_constraint c "
    7364             :                           "ON (i.indrelid = c.conrelid AND "
    7365             :                           "i.indexrelid = c.conindid AND "
    7366             :                           "c.contype IN ('p','u','x')) "
    7367             :                           "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_inherits inh "
    7368             :                           "ON (inh.inhrelid = indexrelid) "
    7369             :                           "WHERE (i.indisvalid OR t2.relkind = 'p') "
    7370             :                           "AND i.indisready "
    7371             :                           "ORDER BY i.indrelid, indexname",
    7372             :                           tbloids->data);
    7373             :     }
    7374             :     else
    7375             :     {
    7376             :         /*
    7377             :          * the test on indisready is necessary in 9.2, and harmless in
    7378             :          * earlier/later versions
    7379             :          */
    7380           0 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    7381             :                           "FROM unnest('%s'::pg_catalog.oid[]) AS src(tbloid)\n"
    7382             :                           "JOIN pg_catalog.pg_index i ON (src.tbloid = i.indrelid) "

    7615             : /*
    7616             :  * getConstraints
    7617             :  *
    7618             :  * Get info about constraints on dumpable tables.
    7619             :  *
    7620             :  * Currently handles foreign keys only.
    7621             :  * Unique and primary key constraints are handled with indexes,
    7622             :  * while check constraints are processed in getTableAttrs().
    7623             :  */
    7624             : void
    7625         294 : getConstraints(Archive *fout, TableInfo tblinfo[], int numTables)
    7626             : {
    7627         294 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
    7628         294 :     PQExpBuffer tbloids = createPQExpBuffer();
    7629             :     PGresult   *res;
    7630             :     int         ntups;
    7631             :     int         curtblindx;
    7632         294 :     TableInfo  *tbinfo = NULL;
    7633             :     ConstraintInfo *constrinfo;
    7634             :     int         i_contableoid,
    7635             :                 i_conoid,
    7636             :                 i_conrelid,
    7637             :                 i_conname,
    7638             :                 i_confrelid,
    7639             :                 i_conindid,
    7640             :                 i_condef;
    7641             : 
    7642             :     /*
    7643             :      * We want to perform just one query against pg_constraint.  However, we
    7644             :      * mustn't try to select every row of the catalog and then sort it out on
    7645             :      * the client side, because some of the server-side functions we need
    7646             :      * would be unsafe to apply to tables we don't have lock on.  Hence, we
    7647             :      * build an array of the OIDs of tables we care about (and now have lock
    7648             :      * on!), and use a WHERE clause to constrain which rows are selected.
    7649             :      */
    7650         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '{');
    7651       74222 :     for (int i = 0; i < numTables; i++)
    7652             :     {
    7653       73928 :         TableInfo  *tinfo = &tblinfo[i];
    7654             : 
    7655             :         /*
    7656             :          * For partitioned tables, foreign keys have no triggers so they must
    7657             :          * be included anyway in case some foreign keys are defined.
    7658             :          */

    7749         292 :         reftable = findTableByOid(constrinfo[j].confrelid);

    7777             : 
    7778             : /*
    7779             :  * addConstrChildIdxDeps
    7780             :  *
    7781             :  * Recursive subroutine for getConstraints
    7782             :  *
    7783             :  * Given an object representing a foreign key constraint and an index on the
    7784             :  * partitioned table it references, mark the constraint object as dependent
    7785             :  * on the DO_INDEX_ATTACH object of each index partition, recursively
    7786             :  * drilling down to their partitions if any.  This ensures that the FK is not
    7787             :  * restored until the index is fully marked valid.
    7788             :  */
    7789             : static void
    7790          90 : addConstrChildIdxDeps(DumpableObject *dobj, const IndxInfo *refidx)
    7791             : {
    7792             :     SimplePtrListCell *cell;
    7793             : 
    7794          90 :     Assert(dobj->objType == DO_FK_CONSTRAINT);
    7795             : 
    7796         310 :     for (cell = refidx->partattaches.head; cell; cell = cell->next)
    7797             :     {

    7998             : /*
    7999             :  * getTriggers
    8000             :  *    get information about every trigger on a dumpable table
    8001             :  *
    8002             :  * Note: trigger data is not returned directly to the caller, but it
    8003             :  * does get entered into the DumpableObject tables.
    8004             :  */
    8005             : void
    8006         294 : getTriggers(Archive *fout, TableInfo tblinfo[], int numTables)
    8007             : {
    8008         294 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
    8009         294 :     PQExpBuffer tbloids = createPQExpBuffer();
    8010             :     PGresult   *res;
    8011             :     int         ntups;
    8012             :     int         curtblindx;
    8013             :     TriggerInfo *tginfo;
    8014             :     int         i_tableoid,
    8015             :                 i_oid,
    8016             :                 i_tgrelid,
    8017             :                 i_tgname,
    8018             :                 i_tgenabled,
    8019             :                 i_tgispartition,
    8020             :                 i_tgdef;
    8021             : 
    8022             :     /*
    8023             :      * We want to perform just one query against pg_trigger.  However, we
    8024             :      * mustn't try to select every row of the catalog and then sort it out on
    8025             :      * the client side, because some of the server-side functions we need
    8026             :      * would be unsafe to apply to tables we don't have lock on.  Hence, we
    8027             :      * build an array of the OIDs of tables we care about (and now have lock
    8028             :      * on!), and use a WHERE clause to constrain which rows are selected.
    8029             :      */
    8030         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '{');
    8031       74222 :     for (int i = 0; i < numTables; i++)
    8032             :     {
    8033       73928 :         TableInfo  *tbinfo = &tblinfo[i];
    8034             : 
    8035       73928 :         if (!tbinfo->hastriggers ||
    8036        1594 :             !(tbinfo->dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION))
    8037       72450 :             continue;
    8038             : 
    8039             :         /* OK, we need info for this table */
    8040        1478 :         if (tbloids->len > 1) /* do we have more than the '{'? */
    8041        1386 :             appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, ',');
    8042        1478 :         appendPQExpBuffer(tbloids, "%u", tbinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
    8043             :     }
    8044         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '}');
    8045             : 
    8046         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 150000)
    8047             :     {
    8048             :         /*
    8049             :          * NB: think not to use pretty=true in pg_get_triggerdef.  It could
    8050             :          * result in non-forward-compatible dumps of WHEN clauses due to
    8051             :          * under-parenthesization.
    8052             :          *
    8053             :          * NB: We need to see partition triggers in case the tgenabled flag
    8054             :          * has been changed from the parent.
    8055             :          */
    8056         294 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
    8057             :                           "SELECT t.tgrelid, t.tgname, "

    8578             : /*
    8579             :  * getTableAttrs -
    8580             :  *    for each interesting table, read info about its attributes
    8581             :  *    (names, types, default values, CHECK constraints, etc)
    8582             :  *
    8583             :  *  modifies tblinfo
    8584             :  */
    8585             : void
    8586         294 : getTableAttrs(Archive *fout, TableInfo *tblinfo, int numTables)
    8587             : {
    8588         294 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
    8589         294 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();
    8590         294 :     PQExpBuffer tbloids = createPQExpBuffer();
    8591         294 :     PQExpBuffer checkoids = createPQExpBuffer();
    8592             :     PGresult   *res;
    8593             :     int         ntups;
    8594             :     int         curtblindx;
    8595             :     int         i_attrelid;
    8596             :     int         i_attnum;
    8597             :     int         i_attname;
    8598             :     int         i_atttypname;
    8599             :     int         i_attstattarget;
    8600             :     int         i_attstorage;
    8601             :     int         i_typstorage;
    8602             :     int         i_attidentity;
    8603             :     int         i_attgenerated;
    8604             :     int         i_attisdropped;
    8605             :     int         i_attlen;
    8606             :     int         i_attalign;
    8607             :     int         i_attislocal;
    8608             :     int         i_notnull_name;
    8609             :     int         i_notnull_noinherit;
    8610             :     int         i_notnull_is_pk;
    8611             :     int         i_notnull_inh;
    8612             :     int         i_attoptions;
    8613             :     int         i_attcollation;
    8614             :     int         i_attcompression;
    8615             :     int         i_attfdwoptions;
    8616             :     int         i_attmissingval;
    8617             :     int         i_atthasdef;
    8618             : 
    8619             :     /*
    8620             :      * We want to perform just one query against pg_attribute, and then just
    8621             :      * one against pg_attrdef (for DEFAULTs) and two against pg_constraint
    8622             :      * (for CHECK constraints and for NOT NULL constraints).  However, we
    8623             :      * mustn't try to select every row of those catalogs and then sort it out
    8624             :      * on the client side, because some of the server-side functions we need
    8625             :      * would be unsafe to apply to tables we don't have lock on.  Hence, we
    8626             :      * build an array of the OIDs of tables we care about (and now have lock
    8627             :      * on!), and use a WHERE clause to constrain which rows are selected.
    8628             :      */
    8629         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '{');
    8630         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(checkoids, '{');
    8631       74222 :     for (int i = 0; i < numTables; i++)
    8632             :     {
    8633       73928 :         TableInfo  *tbinfo = &tblinfo[i];
    8634             : 
    8635             :         /* Don't bother to collect info for sequences */
    8636       73928 :         if (tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_SEQUENCE)
    8637         974 :             continue;
    8638             : 
    8639             :         /* Don't bother with uninteresting tables, either */
    8640       72954 :         if (!tbinfo->interesting)
    8641       62838 :             continue;
    8642             : 
    8643             :         /* OK, we need info for this table */
    8644       10116 :         if (tbloids->len > 1) /* do we have more than the '{'? */
    8645        9926 :             appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, ',');
    8646       10116 :         appendPQExpBuffer(tbloids, "%u", tbinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
    8647             : 
    8648       10116 :         if (tbinfo->ncheck > 0)
    8649             :         {
    8650             :             /* Also make a list of the ones with check constraints */
    8651         836 :             if (checkoids->len > 1) /* do we have more than the '{'? */
    8652         710 :                 appendPQExpBufferChar(checkoids, ',');
    8653         836 :             appendPQExpBuffer(checkoids, "%u", tbinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
    8654             :         }
    8655             :     }
    8656         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(tbloids, '}');
    8657         294 :     appendPQExpBufferChar(checkoids, '}');
    8658             : 
    8659             :     /*
    8660             :      * Find all the user attributes and their types.
    8661             :      *
    8662             :      * Since we only want to dump COLLATE clauses for attributes whose
    8663             :      * collation is different from their type's default, we use a CASE here to
    8664             :      * suppress uninteresting attcollations cheaply.
    8665             :      */
    8666         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8667             :                          "SELECT\n"
    8668             :                          "a.attrelid,\n"
    8669             :                          "a.attnum,\n"
    8670             :                          "a.attname,\n"
    8671             :                          "a.attstattarget,\n"
    8672             :                          "a.attstorage,\n"
    8673             :                          "t.typstorage,\n"
    8674             :                          "a.atthasdef,\n"
    8675             :                          "a.attisdropped,\n"
    8676             :                          "a.attlen,\n"
    8677             :                          "a.attalign,\n"
    8678             :                          "a.attislocal,\n"
    8679             :                          "pg_catalog.format_type(t.oid, a.atttypmod) AS atttypname,\n"
    8680             :                          "array_to_string(a.attoptions, ', ') AS attoptions,\n"
    8681             :                          "CASE WHEN a.attcollation <> t.typcollation "
    8682             :                          "THEN a.attcollation ELSE 0 END AS attcollation,\n"
    8683             :                          "pg_catalog.array_to_string(ARRAY("
    8684             :                          "SELECT pg_catalog.quote_ident(option_name) || "
    8685             :                          "' ' || pg_catalog.quote_literal(option_value) "
    8686             :                          "FROM pg_catalog.pg_options_to_table(attfdwoptions) "
    8687             :                          "ORDER BY option_name"
    8688             :                          "), E',\n    ') AS attfdwoptions,\n");
    8689             : 
    8690             :     /*
    8691             :      * Find out any NOT NULL markings for each column.  In 17 and up we have
    8692             :      * to read pg_constraint, and keep track whether it's NO INHERIT; in older
    8693             :      * versions we rely on pg_attribute.attnotnull.
    8694             :      *
    8695             :      * We also track whether the constraint was defined directly in this table
    8696             :      * or via an ancestor, for binary upgrade.
    8697             :      *
    8698             :      * Lastly, we need to know if the PK for the table involves each column;
    8699             :      * for columns that are there we need a NOT NULL marking even if there's
    8700             :      * no explicit constraint, to avoid the table having to be scanned for
    8701             :      * NULLs after the data is loaded when the PK is created, later in the
    8702             :      * dump; for this case we add throwaway constraints that are dropped once
    8703             :      * the PK is created.
    8704             :      */
    8705         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 170000)
    8706         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8707             :                              "co.conname AS notnull_name,\n"
    8708             :                              "co.connoinherit AS notnull_noinherit,\n"
    8709             :                              "copk.conname IS NOT NULL as notnull_is_pk,\n"
    8710             :                              "coalesce(NOT co.conislocal, true) AS notnull_inh,\n");
    8711             :     else
    8712           0 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8713             :                              "CASE WHEN a.attnotnull THEN '' ELSE NULL END AS notnull_name,\n"
    8714             :                              "false AS notnull_noinherit,\n"
    8715             :                              "copk.conname IS NOT NULL AS notnull_is_pk,\n"
    8716             :                              "NOT a.attislocal AS notnull_inh,\n");
    8717             : 
    8718         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 140000)
    8719         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8720             :                              "a.attcompression AS attcompression,\n");
    8721             :     else
    8722           0 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8723             :                              "'' AS attcompression,\n");
    8724             : 
    8725         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 100000)
    8726         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8727             :                              "a.attidentity,\n");
    8728             :     else
    8729           0 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8730             :                              "'' AS attidentity,\n");
    8731             : 
    8732         294 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 110000)
    8733         294 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
    8734             :                              "CASE WHEN a.atthasmissing AND NOT a.attisdropped "
    8735             :                              "THEN a.attmissingval ELSE null END AS attmissingval,\n");
    8736             :     else

    8738             :                              "NULL AS attmissingval,\n");

    8891       37966 :             tbinfo->attlen[j] = atoi(PQgetvalue(res, r, i_attlen));
    8892       37966 :             tbinfo->attalign[j] = *(PQgetvalue(res, r, i_attalign));
    8893       37966 :             tbinfo->attislocal[j] = (PQgetvalue(res, r, i_attislocal)[0] == 't');
    8894             : 
    8895             :             /*
    8896             :              * Not-null constraints require a jumping through a few hoops.
    8897             :              * First, if the user has specified a constraint name that's not
    8898             :              * the system-assigned default name, then we need to preserve
    8899             :              * that. But if they haven't, then we don't want to use the
    8900             :              * verbose syntax in the dump output. (Also, in versions prior to
    8901             :              * 17, there was no constraint name at all.)
    8902             :              *
    8903             :              * (XXX Comparing the name this way to a supposed default name is
    8904             :              * a bit of a hack, but it beats having to store a boolean flag in
    8905             :              * pg_constraint just for this, or having to compute the knowledge
    8906             :              * at pg_dump time from the server.)
    8907             :              *
    8908             :              * We also need to know if a column is part of the primary key. In
    8909             :              * that case, we want to mark the column as not-null at table
    8910             :              * creation time, so that the table doesn't have to be scanned to
    8911             :              * check for nulls when the PK is created afterwards; this is
    8912             :              * especially critical during pg_upgrade (where the data would not
    8913             :              * be scanned at all otherwise.)  If the column is part of the PK
    8914             :              * and does not have any other not-null constraint, then we
    8915             :              * fabricate a throwaway constraint name that we later use to
    8916             :              * remove the constraint after the PK has been created.
    8917             :              *
    8918             :              * For inheritance child tables, we don't want to print not-null
    8919             :              * when the constraint was defined at the parent level instead of
    8920             :              * locally.
    8921             :              */
    8922             : 
    8923             :             /*
    8924             :              * We use notnull_inh to suppress unwanted not-null constraints in
    8925             :              * inheritance children, when said constraints come from the
    8926             :              * parent(s).
    8927             :              */
    8928       37966 :             tbinfo->notnull_inh[j] = PQgetvalue(res, r, i_notnull_inh)[0] == 't';
    8929             : 
    8930       37966 :             if (fout->remoteVersion < 170000)
    8931             :             {
    8932           0 :                 if (!PQgetisnull(res, r, i_notnull_name) &&
    8933           0 :                     dopt->binary_upgrade &&
    8934           0 :                     !tbinfo->ispartition &&
    8935           0 :                     tbinfo->notnull_inh[j])
    8936             :                 {
    8937           0 :                     use_named_notnull = true;
    8938             :                     /* XXX should match ChooseConstraintName better */
    8939           0 :                     tbinfo->notnull_constrs[j] =
    8940           0 :                         psprintf("%s_%s_not_null", tbinfo->dobj.name,
    8941           0 :                                  tbinfo->attnames[j]);
    8942             :                 }
    8943           0 :                 else if (PQgetvalue(res, r, i_notnull_is_pk)[0] == 't')
    8944           0 :                     use_throwaway_notnull = true;
    8945           0 :                 else if (!PQgetisnull(res, r, i_notnull_name))
    8946           0 :                     use_unnamed_notnull = true;
    8947             :             }
    8948             :             else
    8949             :             {
    8950       37966 :                 if (!PQgetisnull(res, r, i_notnull_name))
    8951             :                 {

    8953             :                      * In binary upgrade of inheritance child tables, must
    8954             :                      * have a constraint name that we can UPDATE later.
    8955             :                      */

    8963             :

    8973        2152 :                                    PQgetvalue(res, r, i_notnull_name)) == 0)
    8974        1370 :                             use_unnamed_notnull = true;

    8976             :                         {

    9113             :             /*
    9114             :              * Figure out whether the default/generation expression should be
    9115             :              * dumped as part of the main CREATE TABLE (or similar) command or
    9116             :              * as a separate ALTER TABLE (or similar) command. The preference
    9117             :              * is to put it into the CREATE command, but in some cases that's
    9118             :              * not possible.
    9119             :              */

    9121             :             {

    9123             :                  * Column generation expressions cannot be dumped separately,
    9124             :                  * because there is no syntax for it.  By setting separate to
    9125             :                  * false here we prevent the "default" from being processed as

    9130         660 :                 attrdefs[j].separate = false;
    9131             :             }

    9303         294 : }
    9304             : 
    9305             : /*
    9306             :  * Test whether a column should be printed as part of table's CREATE TABLE.
    9307             :  * Column number is zero-based.
    9308             :  *
    9309             :  * Normally this is always true, but it's false for dropped columns, as well
    9310             :  * as those that were inherited without any local definition.  (If we print
    9311             :  * such a column it will mistakenly get pg_attribute.attislocal set to true.)
    9312             :  * For partitions, it's always true, because we want the partitions to be
    9313             :  * created independently and ATTACH PARTITION used afterwards.
    9314             :  *
    9315             :  * In binary_upgrade mode, we must print all columns and fix the attislocal/
    9316             :  * attisdropped state later, so as to keep control of the physical column
    9317             :  * order.
    9318             :  *
    9319             :  * This function exists because there are scattered nonobvious places that
    9320             :  * must be kept in sync with this decision.
    9321             :  */
    9322             : bool
    9323       68472 : shouldPrintColumn(const DumpOptions *dopt, const TableInfo *tbinfo, int colno)
    9324             : {
    9325       68472 :     if (dopt->binary_upgrade)
    9326       11558 :         return true;
    9327       56914 :     if (tbinfo->attisdropped[colno])
    9328         682 :         return false;
    9329       56232 :     return (tbinfo->attislocal[colno] || tbinfo->ispartition);
    9330             : }
    9331             : 
    9332             : 
    9333             : /*
    9334             :  * getTSParsers:

    9799             : /*
    9800             :  * getDefaultACLs:
    9801             :  *    read all default ACL information in the system catalogs and return

    9806             : DefaultACLInfo *
    9807         294 : getDefaultACLs(Archive *fout, int *numDefaultACLs)
    9808             : {
    9809         294 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
    9810             :     DefaultACLInfo *daclinfo;
    9811             :     PQExpBuffer query;
    9812             :     PGresult   *res;
    9813             :     int         i_oid;
    9814             :     int         i_tableoid;
    9815             :     int         i_defaclrole;
    9816             :     int         i_defaclnamespace;
    9817             :     int         i_defaclobjtype;
    9818             :     int         i_defaclacl;
    9819             :     int         i_acldefault;
    9820             :     int         i,
    9821             :                 ntups;
    9822             : 
    9823         294 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
    9824             : 
    9825             :     /*
    9826             :      * Global entries (with defaclnamespace=0) replace the hard-wired default
    9827             :      * ACL for their object type.  We should dump them as deltas from the
    9828             :      * default ACL, since that will be used as a starting point for
    9829             :      * interpreting the ALTER DEFAULT PRIVILEGES commands.  On the other hand,
    9830             :      * non-global entries can only add privileges not revoke them.  We must
    9831             :      * dump those as-is (i.e., as deltas from an empty ACL).
    9832             :      *
    9833             :      * We can use defaclobjtype as the object type for acldefault(), except
    9834             :      * for the case of 'S' (DEFACLOBJ_SEQUENCE) which must be converted to
    9835             :      * 's'.
    9836             :      */
    9837         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    9838             :                          "SELECT oid, tableoid, "
    9839             :                          "defaclrole, "
    9840             :                          "defaclnamespace, "
    9841             :                          "defaclobjtype, "
    9842             :                          "defaclacl, "
    9843             :                          "CASE WHEN defaclnamespace = 0 THEN "
    9844             :                          "acldefault(CASE WHEN defaclobjtype = 'S' "
    9845             :                          "THEN 's'::\"char\" ELSE defaclobjtype END, "
    9846             :                          "defaclrole) ELSE '{}' END AS acldefault "
    9847             :                          "FROM pg_default_acl");
    9848             : 
    9849         294 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    9850             : 
    9851         294 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
    9852         294 :     *numDefaultACLs = ntups;
    9853             : 
    9854         294 :     daclinfo = (DefaultACLInfo *) pg_malloc(ntups * sizeof(DefaultACLInfo));
    9855             :

    9857         294 :     i_tableoid = PQfnumber(res, "tableoid");

    9859         294 :     i_defaclnamespace = PQfnumber(res, "defaclnamespace");
    9860         294 :     i_defaclobjtype = PQfnumber(res, "defaclobjtype");
    9861         294 :     i_defaclacl = PQfnumber(res, "defaclacl");

    9901             : /*
    9902             :  * getRoleName -- look up the name of a role, given its OID
    9903             :  *
    9904             :  * In current usage, we don't expect failures, so error out for a bad OID.
    9905             :  */
    9906             : static const char *
    9907      910834 : getRoleName(const char *roleoid_str)
    9908             : {
    9909      910834 :     Oid         roleoid = atooid(roleoid_str);
    9910             : 
    9911             :     /*
    9912             :      * Do binary search to find the appropriate item.
    9913             :      */
    9914      910834 :     if (nrolenames > 0)
    9915             :     {
    9916      910834 :         RoleNameItem *low = &rolenames[0];
    9917      910834 :         RoleNameItem *high = &rolenames[nrolenames - 1];
    9918             : 
    9919     3643106 :         while (low <= high)
    9920             :         {
    9921     3643106 :             RoleNameItem *middle = low + (high - low) / 2;
    9922             : 
    9923     3643106 :             if (roleoid < middle->roleoid)
    9924     2730424 :                 high = middle - 1;
    9925      912682 :             else if (roleoid > middle->roleoid)
    9926        1848 :                 low = middle + 1;
    9927             :             else
    9928      910834 :                 return middle->rolename; /* found a match */
    9929             :         }
    9930             :     }
    9931             : 
    9932           0 :     pg_fatal("role with OID %u does not exist", roleoid);
    9933             :     return NULL;                /* keep compiler quiet */
    9934             : }
    9935             : 
    9936             : /*
    9937             :  * collectRoleNames --

    9940             :  * The table is sorted by OID for speed in lookup.

    9965             : 
    9966             : /*
    9967             :  * getAdditionalACLs
    9968             :  *
    9969             :  * We have now created all the DumpableObjects, and collected the ACL data
    9970             :  * that appears in the directly-associated catalog entries.  However, there's
    9971             :  * more ACL-related info to collect.  If any of a table's columns have ACLs,
    9972             :  * we must set the TableInfo's DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL components flag, as well as
    9973             :  * its hascolumnACLs flag (we won't store the ACLs themselves here, though).
    9974             :  * Also, in versions having the pg_init_privs catalog, read that and load the
    9975             :  * information into the relevant DumpableObjects.
    9976             :  */
    9977             : static void
    9978         290 : getAdditionalACLs(Archive *fout)
    9979             : {
    9980         290 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
    9981             :     PGresult   *res;
    9982             :     int         ntups,
    9983             :                 i;
    9984             : 
    9985             :     /* Check for per-column ACLs */
    9986         290 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
    9987             :                          "SELECT DISTINCT attrelid FROM pg_attribute "
    9988             :                          "WHERE attacl IS NOT NULL");
    9989             : 
    9990         290 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
    9991             :

   10082             : 
   10083             : /*
   10084             :  * dumpCommentExtended --
   10085             :  *
   10086             :  * This routine is used to dump any comments associated with the
   10087             :  * object handed to this routine. The routine takes the object type
   10088             :  * and object name (ready to print, except for schema decoration), plus
   10089             :  * the namespace and owner of the object (for labeling the ArchiveEntry),
   10090             :  * plus catalog ID and subid which are the lookup key for pg_description,
   10091             :  * plus the dump ID for the object (for setting a dependency).
   10092             :  * If a matching pg_description entry is found, it is dumped.
   10093             :  *
   10094             :  * Note: in some cases, such as comments for triggers and rules, the "type"
   10095             :  * string really looks like, e.g., "TRIGGER name ON".  This is a bit of a hack
   10096             :  * but it doesn't seem worth complicating the API for all callers to make
   10097             :  * it cleaner.
   10098             :  *
   10099             :  * Note: although this routine takes a dumpId for dependency purposes,
   10100             :  * that purpose is just to mark the dependency in the emitted dump file
   10101             :  * for possible future use by pg_restore.  We do NOT use it for determining
   10102             :  * ordering of the comment in the dump file, because this routine is called
   10103             :  * after dependency sorting occurs.  This routine should be called just after
   10104             :  * calling ArchiveEntry() for the specified object.
   10105             :  */
   10106             : static void
   10107        5034 : dumpCommentExtended(Archive *fout, const char *type,
   10108             :                     const char *name, const char *namespace,
   10109             :                     const char *owner, CatalogId catalogId,
   10110             :                     int subid, DumpId dumpId,
   10111             :                     const char *initdb_comment)
   10112             : {
   10113        5034 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   10114             :     CommentItem *comments;
   10115             :     int         ncomments;
   10116             : 
   10117             :     /* do nothing, if --no-comments is supplied */
   10118        5034 :     if (dopt->no_comments)
   10119           0 :         return;
   10120             : 
   10121             :     /* Comments are schema not data ... except LO comments are data */
   10122        5034 :     if (strcmp(type, "LARGE OBJECT") != 0)
   10123             :     {
   10124        4952 :         if (dopt->dataOnly)
   10125           0 :             return;
   10126             :     }
   10127             :     else
   10128             :     {
   10129             :         /* We do dump LO comments in binary-upgrade mode */

   10131           0 :             return;

   10216             : /*
   10217             :  * dumpTableComment --

   10312             : 
   10313             : /*
   10314             :  * findComments --
   10315             :  *
   10316             :  * Find the comment(s), if any, associated with the given object.  All the
   10317             :  * objsubid values associated with the given classoid/objoid are found with
   10318             :  * one search.
   10319             :  */
   10320             : static int
   10321        5234 : findComments(Oid classoid, Oid objoid, CommentItem **items)
   10322             : {
   10323        5234 :     CommentItem *middle = NULL;
   10324             :     CommentItem *low;
   10325             :     CommentItem *high;
   10326             :     int         nmatch;
   10327             : 
   10328             :     /*
   10329             :      * Do binary search to find some item matching the object.
   10330             :      */
   10331        5234 :     low = &comments[0];
   10332        5234 :     high = &comments[ncomments - 1];
   10333       52230 :     while (low <= high)
   10334             :     {
   10335       52162 :         middle = low + (high - low) / 2;
   10336             : 
   10337       52162 :         if (classoid < middle->classoid)
   10338        8506 :             high = middle - 1;
   10339       43656 :         else if (classoid > middle->classoid)
   10340        7454 :             low = middle + 1;
   10341       36202 :         else if (objoid < middle->objoid)
   10342       14360 :             high = middle - 1;
   10343       21842 :         else if (objoid > middle->objoid)
   10344       16676 :             low = middle + 1;
   10345             :         else
   10346        5166 :             break;              /* found a match */
   10347             :     }
   10348             : 
   10349        5234 :     if (low > high)              /* no matches */
   10350             :     {
   10351          68 :         *items = NULL;
   10352          68 :         return 0;
   10353             :     }
   10354             : 
   10355             :     /*
   10356             :      * Now determine how many items match the object.  The search loop
   10357             :      * invariant still holds: only items between low and high inclusive could
   10358             :      * match.
   10359             :      */
   10360        5166 :     nmatch = 1;
   10361        5166 :     while (middle > low)
   10362             :     {
   10363        2364 :         if (classoid != middle[-1].classoid ||
   10364        2218 :             objoid != middle[-1].objoid)
   10365             :             break;
   10366           0 :         middle--;
   10367           0 :         nmatch++;
   10368             :     }
   10369             : 
   10370        5166 :     *items = middle;
   10371             : 
   10372        5166 :     middle += nmatch;
   10373        5286 :     while (middle <= high)
   10374             :     {
   10375        2688 :         if (classoid != middle->classoid ||
   10376        2256 :             objoid != middle->objoid)
   10377             :             break;
   10378         120 :         middle++;
   10379         120 :         nmatch++;
   10380             :     }
   10381             : 
   10382        5166 :     return nmatch;
   10383             : }
   10384             : 
   10385             : /*
   10386             :  * collectComments --
   10387             :  *
   10388             :  * Construct a table of all comments available for database objects;
   10389             :  * also set the has-comment component flag for each relevant object.
   10390             :  *
   10391             :  * We used to do per-object queries for the comments, but it's much faster
   10392             :  * to pull them all over at once, and on most databases the memory cost
   10393             :  * isn't high.
   10394             :  *
   10395             :  * The table is sorted by classoid/objid/objsubid for speed in lookup.
   10396             :  */
   10397             : static void
   10398         294 : collectComments(Archive *fout)
   10399             : {
   10400             :     PGresult   *res;
   10401             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   10402             :     int         i_description;
   10403             :     int         i_classoid;
   10404             :     int         i_objoid;
   10405             :     int         i_objsubid;
   10406             :     int         ntups;
   10407             :     int         i;
   10408             :     DumpableObject *dobj;
   10409             : 
   10410         294 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   10411             : 
   10412         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT description, classoid, objoid, objsubid "
   10413             :                          "FROM pg_catalog.pg_description "
   10414             :                          "ORDER BY classoid, objoid, objsubid");
   10415             : 
   10416         294 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   10417             : 
   10418             :     /* Construct lookup table containing OIDs in numeric form */
   10419             : 
   10420         294 :     i_description = PQfnumber(res, "description");
   10421         294 :     i_classoid = PQfnumber(res, "classoid");
   10422         294 :     i_objoid = PQfnumber(res, "objoid");
   10423         294 :     i_objsubid = PQfnumber(res, "objsubid");
   10424             : 
   10425         294 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   10426             : 
   10427         294 :     comments = (CommentItem *) pg_malloc(ntups * sizeof(CommentItem));
   10428         294 :     ncomments = 0;
   10429         294 :     dobj = NULL;
   10430             : 
   10431     1531146 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
   10432             :     {
   10433             :         CatalogId   objId;
   10434             :         int         subid;
   10435             : 
   10436     1530852 :         objId.tableoid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_classoid));
   10437     1530852 :         objId.oid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_objoid));
   10438     1530852 :         subid = atoi(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_objsubid));
   10439             : 
   10440             :         /* We needn't remember comments that don't match any dumpable object */

   10445     1530852 :         if (dobj == NULL)
   10446      973372 :             continue;
   10447             : 
   10448             :         /*
   10449             :          * Comments on columns of composite types are linked to the type's
   10450             :          * pg_class entry, but we need to set the DUMP_COMPONENT_COMMENT flag
   10451             :          * in the type's own DumpableObject.
   10452             :          */

   10471             : 
   10472         294 :     PQclear(res);
   10473         294 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
   10474         294 : }
   10475             : 
   10476             : /*
   10477             :  * dumpDumpableObject
   10478             :  *
   10479             :  * This routine and its subsidiaries are responsible for creating
   10480             :  * ArchiveEntries (TOC objects) for each object to be dumped.
   10481             :  */
   10482             : static void
   10483     1060084 : dumpDumpableObject(Archive *fout, DumpableObject *dobj)
   10484             : {
   10485             :     /*
   10486             :      * Clear any dump-request bits for components that don't exist for this
   10487             :      * object.  (This makes it safe to initially use DUMP_COMPONENT_ALL as the
   10488             :      * request for every kind of object.)
   10489             :      */
   10490     1060084 :     dobj->dump &= dobj->components;
   10491             : 
   10492             :     /* Now, short-circuit if there's nothing to be done here. */
   10493     1060084 :     if (dobj->dump == 0)
   10494      953000 :         return;
   10495             : 
   10496      107084 :     switch (dobj->objType)
   10497             :     {
   10498         738 :         case DO_NAMESPACE:
   10499         738 :             dumpNamespace(fout, (const NamespaceInfo *) dobj);
   10500         738 :             break;
   10501          38 :         case DO_EXTENSION:

   10617          72 :                 te = ArchiveEntry(fout, dobj->catId, dobj->dumpId,

   10623             :                 /*
   10624             :                  * Set the TocEntry's dataLength in case we are doing a
   10625             :                  * parallel dump and want to order dump jobs by table size.
   10626             :                  * (We need some size estimate for every TocEntry with a
   10627             :                  * DataDumper function.)  We don't currently have any cheap
   10628             :                  * way to estimate the size of LOs, but it doesn't matter;
   10629             :                  * let's just set the size to a large value so parallel dumps
   10630             :                  * will launch this job first.  If there's lots of LOs, we
   10631             :                  * win, and if there aren't, we don't lose much.  (If you want
   10632             :                  * to improve on this, really what you should be thinking
   10633             :                  * about is allowing LO dumping to be parallelized, not just
   10634             :                  * getting a smarter estimate for the single TOC entry.)
   10635             :                  */
   10636          72 :                 te->dataLength = INT_MAX;
   10637             :             }
   10638          72 :             break;

   10742             : /*
   10743             :  * dumpExtension
   10744             :  *    writes out to fout the queries to recreate an extension
   10745             :  */
   10746             : static void
   10747          38 : dumpExtension(Archive *fout, const ExtensionInfo *extinfo)
   10748             : {
   10749          38 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   10750             :     PQExpBuffer q;
   10751             :     PQExpBuffer delq;
   10752             :     char       *qextname;
   10753             : 
   10754             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump */
   10755          38 :     if (dopt->dataOnly)
   10756           2 :         return;
   10757             : 
   10758          36 :     q = createPQExpBuffer();
   10759          36 :     delq = createPQExpBuffer();
   10760             : 
   10761          36 :     qextname = pg_strdup(fmtId(extinfo->dobj.name));
   10762             : 
   10763          36 :     appendPQExpBuffer(delq, "DROP EXTENSION %s;\n", qextname);
   10764             : 
   10765          36 :     if (!dopt->binary_upgrade)
   10766             :     {
   10767             :         /*
   10768             :          * In a regular dump, we simply create the extension, intentionally
   10769             :          * not specifying a version, so that the destination installation's
   10770             :          * default version is used.
   10771             :          *
   10772             :          * Use of IF NOT EXISTS here is unlike our behavior for other object
   10773             :          * types; but there are various scenarios in which it's convenient to
   10774             :          * manually create the desired extension before restoring, so we
   10775             :          * prefer to allow it to exist already.
   10776             :          */
   10777          34 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, "CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS %s WITH SCHEMA %s;\n",
   10778          34 :                           qextname, fmtId(extinfo->namespace));
   10779             :     }
   10780             :     else
   10781             :     {
   10782             :         /*
   10783             :          * In binary-upgrade mode, it's critical to reproduce the state of the
   10784             :          * database exactly, so our procedure is to create an empty extension,
   10785             :          * restore all the contained objects normally, and add them to the
   10786             :          * extension one by one.  This function performs just the first of
   10787             :          * those steps.  binary_upgrade_extension_member() takes care of
   10788             :          * adding member objects as they're created.
   10789             :          */
   10790             :         int         i;
   10791             :         int         n;
   10792             : 
   10793           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "-- For binary upgrade, create an empty extension and insert objects into it\n");
   10794             : 
   10795             :         /*
   10796             :          * We unconditionally create the extension, so we must drop it if it
   10797             :          * exists.  This could happen if the user deleted 'plpgsql' and then
   10798             :          * readded it, causing its oid to be greater than g_last_builtin_oid.
   10799             :          */
   10800           2 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, "DROP EXTENSION IF EXISTS %s;\n", qextname);
   10801             : 
   10802           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
   10803             :                              "SELECT pg_catalog.binary_upgrade_create_empty_extension(");
   10804           2 :         appendStringLiteralAH(q, extinfo->dobj.name, fout);
   10805           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
   10806           2 :         appendStringLiteralAH(q, extinfo->namespace, fout);
   10807           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
   10808           2 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, "%s, ", extinfo->relocatable ? "true" : "false");
   10809           2 :         appendStringLiteralAH(q, extinfo->extversion, fout);
   10810           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
   10811             : 
   10812             :         /*
   10813             :          * Note that we're pushing extconfig (an OID array) back into
   10814             :          * pg_extension exactly as-is.  This is OK because pg_class OIDs are
   10815             :          * preserved in binary upgrade.
   10816             :          */
   10817           2 :         if (strlen(extinfo->extconfig) > 2)
   10818           2 :             appendStringLiteralAH(q, extinfo->extconfig, fout);
   10819             :         else
   10820           0 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "NULL");
   10821           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
   10822           2 :         if (strlen(extinfo->extcondition) > 2)
   10823           2 :             appendStringLiteralAH(q, extinfo->extcondition, fout);
   10824             :         else
   10825           0 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "NULL");
   10826           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ", ");
   10827           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "ARRAY[");
   10828           2 :         n = 0;
   10829           4 :         for (i = 0; i < extinfo->dobj.nDeps; i++)
   10830             :         {
   10831             :             DumpableObject *extobj;
   10832             : 
   10833           2 :             extobj = findObjectByDumpId(extinfo->dobj.dependencies[i]);
   10834           2 :             if (extobj && extobj->objType == DO_EXTENSION)
   10835             :             {
   10836           0 :                 if (n++ > 0)
   10837           0 :                     appendPQExpBufferChar(q, ',');
   10838           0 :                 appendStringLiteralAH(q, extobj->name, fout);
   10839             :             }
   10840             :         }
   10841           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "]::pg_catalog.text[]");
   10842           2 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ");\n");
   10843             :     }
   10844             : 
   10845          36 :     if (extinfo->dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION)
   10846          36 :         ArchiveEntry(fout, extinfo->dobj.catId, extinfo->dobj.dumpId,
   10847          36 :                      ARCHIVE_OPTS(.tag = extinfo->dobj.name,
   10848             :                                   .description = "EXTENSION",
   10849             :                                   .section = SECTION_PRE_DATA,
   10850             :                                   .createStmt = q->data,
   10851             :                                   .dropStmt = delq->data));
   10852             :

   10887         230 :         dumpDomain(fout, tyinfo);

   10891          94 :         dumpEnumType(fout, tyinfo);

   10901             : /*
   10902             :  * dumpEnumType

   10904             :  */
   10905             : static void
   10906          94 : dumpEnumType(Archive *fout, const TypeInfo *tyinfo)
   10907             : {
   10908          94 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   10909          94 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();
   10910          94 :     PQExpBuffer delq = createPQExpBuffer();
   10911          94 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
   10912             :     PGresult   *res;
   10913             :     int         num,
   10914             :                 i;
   10915             :     Oid         enum_oid;

   10917             :     char       *qualtypname;

   10920             :     int         i_oid;
   10921             : 
   10922          94 :     if (!fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_DUMPENUMTYPE])
   10923             :     {
   10924             :         /* Set up query for enum-specific details */
   10925          74 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
   10926             :                              "PREPARE dumpEnumType(pg_catalog.oid) AS\n"
   10927             :                              "SELECT oid, enumlabel "
   10928             :                              "FROM pg_catalog.pg_enum "
   10929             :                              "WHERE enumtypid = $1 "
   10930             :                              "ORDER BY enumsortorder");
   10931             : 
   10932          74 :         ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, query->data);
   10933             :

   10935             :     }
   10936             : 
   10937          94 :     printfPQExpBuffer(query,
   10938             :                       "EXECUTE dumpEnumType('%u')",
   10939          94 :                       tyinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
   10940             :

   10942             : 
   10943          94 :     num = PQntuples(res);
   10944             : 
   10945          94 :     qtypname = pg_strdup(fmtId(tyinfo->dobj.name));
   10946          94 :     qualtypname = pg_strdup(fmtQualifiedDumpable(tyinfo));
   10947             :

   10949             :      * CASCADE shouldn't be required here as for normal types since the I/O
   10950             :      * functions are generic and do not get dropped.
   10951             :      */
   10952          94 :     appendPQExpBuffer(delq, "DROP TYPE %s;\n", qualtypname);
   10953             :

   10955           8 :         binary_upgrade_set_type_oids_by_type_oid(fout, q,
   10956           8 :                                                  tyinfo->dobj.catId.oid,
   10957             :                                                  false, false);

   10963             :     {

   10965             : 
   10966             :         /* Labels with server-assigned oids */
   10967         652 :         for (i = 0; i < num; i++)
   10968             :         {
   10969         566 :             label = PQgetvalue(res, i, i_enumlabel);
   10970         566 :             if (i > 0)
   10971         480 :                 appendPQExpBufferChar(q, ',');

   10973         566 :             appendStringLiteralAH(q, label, fout);

   11194             : /*
   11195             :  * dumpUndefinedType
   11196             :  *    writes out to fout the queries to recreate a !typisdefined type
   11197             :  *
   11198             :  * This is a shell type, but we use different terminology to distinguish
   11199             :  * this case from where we have to emit a shell type definition to break
   11200             :  * circular dependencies.  An undefined type shouldn't ever have anything
   11201             :  * depending on it.
   11202             :  */
   11203             : static void
   11204          70 : dumpUndefinedType(Archive *fout, const TypeInfo *tyinfo)
   11205             : {

   11211             :

   11214             : 
   11215          70 :     appendPQExpBuffer(delq, "DROP TYPE %s;\n", qualtypname);
   11216             : 
   11217          70 :     if (dopt->binary_upgrade)
   11218           4 :         binary_upgrade_set_type_oids_by_type_oid(fout, q,
   11219           4 :                                                  tyinfo->dobj.catId.oid,
   11220             :                                                  false, false);

   11222          70 :     appendPQExpBuffer(q, "CREATE TYPE %s;\n",

   11377             : 
   11378             :     /*
   11379             :      * The reason we include CASCADE is that the circular dependency between
   11380             :      * the type and its I/O functions makes it impossible to drop the type any
   11381             :      * other way.
   11382             :      */

   11396             :                       "    INTERNALLENGTH = %s",

   11398         270 :                       (strcmp(typlen, "-1") == 0) ? "variable" : typlen);

   11400             :     /* regproc result is sufficiently quoted already */

   11684             : /*
   11685             :  * dumpCompositeType
   11686             :  *    writes out to fout the queries to recreate a user-defined stand-alone
   11687             :  *    composite type
   11688             :  */
   11689             : static void
   11690         236 : dumpCompositeType(Archive *fout, const TypeInfo *tyinfo)
   11691             : {
   11692         236 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   11693         236 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();
   11694         236 :     PQExpBuffer dropped = createPQExpBuffer();
   11695         236 :     PQExpBuffer delq = createPQExpBuffer();
   11696         236 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
   11697             :     PGresult   *res;
   11698             :     char       *qtypname;
   11699             :     char       *qualtypname;
   11700             :     int         ntups;
   11701             :     int         i_attname;
   11702             :     int         i_atttypdefn;
   11703             :     int         i_attlen;
   11704             :     int         i_attalign;
   11705             :     int         i_attisdropped;
   11706             :     int         i_attcollation;
   11707             :     int         i;
   11708             :     int         actual_atts;
   11709             : 
   11710         236 :     if (!fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_DUMPCOMPOSITETYPE])
   11711             :     {
   11712             :         /*
   11713             :          * Set up query for type-specific details.
   11714             :          *
   11715             :          * Since we only want to dump COLLATE clauses for attributes whose
   11716             :          * collation is different from their type's default, we use a CASE
   11717             :          * here to suppress uninteresting attcollations cheaply.  atttypid
   11718             :          * will be 0 for dropped columns; collation does not matter for those.
   11719             :          */
   11720         106 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
   11721             :                              "PREPARE dumpCompositeType(pg_catalog.oid) AS\n"
   11722             :                              "SELECT a.attname, a.attnum, "
   11723             :                              "pg_catalog.format_type(a.atttypid, a.atttypmod) AS atttypdefn, "
   11724             :                              "a.attlen, a.attalign, a.attisdropped, "
   11725             :                              "CASE WHEN a.attcollation <> at.typcollation "
   11726             :                              "THEN a.attcollation ELSE 0 END AS attcollation "
   11727             :                              "FROM pg_catalog.pg_type ct "
   11728             :                              "JOIN pg_catalog.pg_attribute a ON a.attrelid = ct.typrelid "
   11729             :                              "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_type at ON at.oid = a.atttypid "
   11730             :                              "WHERE ct.oid = $1 "
   11731             :                              "ORDER BY a.attnum");
   11732             : 
   11733         106 :         ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, query->data);
   11734             : 
   11735         106 :         fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_DUMPCOMPOSITETYPE] = true;
   11736             :     }
   11737             : 
   11738         236 :     printfPQExpBuffer(query,
   11739             :                       "EXECUTE dumpCompositeType('%u')",
   11740         236 :                       tyinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
   11741             : 
   11742         236 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   11743             : 
   11744         236 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   11745             : 
   11746         236 :     i_attname = PQfnumber(res, "attname");

   11749         236 :     i_attalign = PQfnumber(res, "attalign");
   11750         236 :     i_attisdropped = PQfnumber(res, "attisdropped");

   11762         236 :     qualtypname = pg_strdup(fmtQualifiedDumpable(tyinfo));
   11763             : 
   11764         236 :     appendPQExpBuffer(q, "CREATE TYPE %s AS (",
   11765             :                       qualtypname);
   11766             :

   11771             :         char       *atttypdefn;

   11797         476 :             if (OidIsValid(attcollation))

   11807             :         else
   11808             :         {
   11809             :             /*
   11810             :              * This is a dropped attribute and we're in binary_upgrade mode.
   11811             :              * Insert a placeholder for it in the CREATE TYPE command, and set

   11833             :         }

   11837             : 
   11838         236 :     appendPQExpBuffer(delq, "DROP TYPE %s;\n", qualtypname);
   11839             :

   11886             : /*
   11887             :  * dumpCompositeTypeColComments
   11888             :  *    writes out to fout the queries to recreate comments on the columns of
   11889             :  *    a user-defined stand-alone composite type.
   11890             :  *
   11891             :  * The caller has already made a query to collect the names and attnums
   11892             :  * of the type's columns, so we just pass that result into here rather
   11893             :  * than reading them again.
   11894             :  */
   11895             : static void
   11896          60 : dumpCompositeTypeColComments(Archive *fout, const TypeInfo *tyinfo,
   11897             :                              PGresult *res)
   11898             : {
   11899             :     CommentItem *comments;
   11900             :     int         ncomments;
   11901             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   11902             :     PQExpBuffer target;
   11903             :     int         i;
   11904             :     int         ntups;
   11905             :     int         i_attname;
   11906             :     int         i_attnum;
   11907             :     int         i_attisdropped;
   11908             : 
   11909             :     /* do nothing, if --no-comments is supplied */
   11910          60 :     if (fout->dopt->no_comments)
   11911           0 :         return;
   11912             : 
   11913             :     /* Search for comments associated with type's pg_class OID */
   11914          60 :     ncomments = findComments(RelationRelationId, tyinfo->typrelid,
   11915             :                              &comments);
   11916             : 
   11917             :     /* If no comments exist, we're done */
   11918          60 :     if (ncomments <= 0)
   11919           0 :         return;
   11920             : 
   11921             :     /* Build COMMENT ON statements */
   11922          60 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   11923          60 :     target = createPQExpBuffer();
   11924             : 
   11925          60 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   11926          60 :     i_attnum = PQfnumber(res, "attnum");
   11927          60 :     i_attname = PQfnumber(res, "attname");
   11928          60 :     i_attisdropped = PQfnumber(res, "attisdropped");
   11929         120 :     while (ncomments > 0)
   11930             :     {
   11931             :         const char *attname;
   11932             : 
   11933          60 :         attname = NULL;
   11934          60 :         for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
   11935             :         {
   11936          60 :             if (atoi(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_attnum)) == comments->objsubid &&
   11937          60 :                 PQgetvalue(res, i, i_attisdropped)[0] != 't')
   11938             :             {
   11939          60 :                 attname = PQgetvalue(res, i, i_attname);
   11940          60 :                 break;
   11941             :             }
   11942             :         }
   11943          60 :         if (attname)            /* just in case we don't find it */
   11944             :         {
   11945          60 :             const char *descr = comments->descr;
   11946             : 
   11947          60 :             resetPQExpBuffer(target);
   11948          60 :             appendPQExpBuffer(target, "COLUMN %s.",
   11949          60 :                               fmtId(tyinfo->dobj.name));
   11950          60 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(target, fmtId(attname));
   11951             : 
   11952          60 :             resetPQExpBuffer(query);
   11953          60 :             appendPQExpBuffer(query, "COMMENT ON COLUMN %s.",
   11954          60 :                               fmtQualifiedDumpable(tyinfo));
   11955          60 :             appendPQExpBuffer(query, "%s IS ", fmtId(attname));
   11956          60 :             appendStringLiteralAH(query, descr, fout);
   11957          60 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(query, ";\n");
   11958             : 
   11959          60 :             ArchiveEntry(fout, nilCatalogId, createDumpId(),
   11960          60 :                          ARCHIVE_OPTS(.tag = target->data,
   11961             :                                       .namespace = tyinfo->dobj.namespace->dobj.name,
   11962             :                                       .owner = tyinfo->rolname,

   11966             :                                       .deps = &(tyinfo->dobj.dumpId),
   11967             :                                       .nDeps = 1));
   11968             :         }
   11969             : 
   11970          60 :         comments++;
   11971          60 :         ncomments--;
   11972             :     }
   11973             : 
   11974          60 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
   11975          60 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(target);

   11978             : /*
   11979             :  * dumpShellType

   11996             :     /*
   11997             :      * Note the lack of a DROP command for the shell type; any required DROP
   11998             :      * is driven off the base type entry, instead.  This interacts with
   11999             :      * _printTocEntry()'s use of the presence of a DROP command to decide
   12000             :      * whether an entry needs an ALTER OWNER command.  We don't want to alter
   12001             :      * the shell type's owner immediately on creation; that should happen only
   12002             :      * after it's filled in, otherwise the backend complains.
   12003             :      */

   12042             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump */
   12043         144 :     if (dopt->dataOnly)
   12044          14 :         return;
   12045             : 
   12046             :     /*
   12047             :      * Try to find the support function(s).  It is not an error if we don't
   12048             :      * find them --- if the functions are in the pg_catalog schema, as is
   12049             :      * standard in 8.1 and up, then we won't have loaded them. (In this case
   12050             :      * we will emit a parameterless CREATE LANGUAGE command, which will
   12051             :      * require PL template knowledge in the backend to reload.)
   12052             :      */

   12155             : /*
   12156             :  * format_function_arguments: generate function name and argument list

   12176             : /*
   12177             :  * format_function_signature: generate function name and argument list
   12178             :  *
   12179             :  * Only a minimal list of input argument types is generated; this is
   12180             :  * sufficient to reference the function, but not to define it.
   12181             :  *

   12183             :  * This is appropriate for use in TOC tags, but not in SQL commands.
   12184             :  */

   12732             : /*
   12733             :  * Dump a transform

   12735             : static void
   12736          74 : dumpTransform(Archive *fout, const TransformInfo *transform)
   12737             : {
   12738          74 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;

   12747             :

   12750           6 :         return;
   12751             : 
   12752             :     /* Cannot dump if we don't have the transform functions' info */

   12761             :     {

   12763          68 :         if (tosqlFuncInfo == NULL)
   12764           0 :             pg_fatal("could not find function definition for function with OID %u",
   12765             :                      transform->trftosql);
