   13074             : /*
   13075             :  * Convert a function reference obtained from pg_operator
   13076             :  *
   13077             :  * Returns allocated string of what to print, or NULL if function references
   13078             :  * is InvalidOid. Returned string is expected to be free'd by the caller.
   13079             :  *
   13080             :  * The input is a REGPROCEDURE display; we have to strip the argument-types
   13081             :  * part.
   13082             :  */
   13083             : static char *
   13084        5304 : convertRegProcReference(const char *proc)
   13085             : {
   13086             :     char       *name;
   13087             :     char       *paren;
   13088             :     bool        inquote;
   13089             : 
   13090             :     /* In all cases "-" means a null reference */
   13091        5304 :     if (strcmp(proc, "-") == 0)
   13092        1464 :         return NULL;
   13093             : 
   13094        3840 :     name = pg_strdup(proc);
   13095             :     /* find non-double-quoted left paren */
   13096        3840 :     inquote = false;
   13097       46172 :     for (paren = name; *paren; paren++)
   13098             :     {
   13099       46172 :         if (*paren == '(' && !inquote)
   13100             :         {
   13101        3840 :             *paren = '\0';
   13102        3840 :             break;
   13103             :         }
   13104       42332 :         if (*paren == '"')
   13105         100 :             inquote = !inquote;
   13106             :     }
   13107        3840 :     return name;
   13108             : }
   13109             : 
   13110             : /*
   13111             :  * getFormattedOperatorName - retrieve the operator name for the
   13112             :  * given operator OID (presented in string form).
   13113             :  *
   13114             :  * Returns an allocated string, or NULL if the given OID is invalid.
   13115             :  * Caller is responsible for free'ing result string.
   13116             :  *
   13117             :  * What we produce has the format "OPERATOR(schema.oprname)".  This is only
   13118             :  * useful in commands where the operator's argument types can be inferred from
   13119             :  * context.  We always schema-qualify the name, though.  The predecessor to
   13120             :  * this code tried to skip the schema qualification if possible, but that led
   13121             :  * to wrong results in corner cases, such as if an operator and its negator
   13122             :  * are in different schemas.
   13123             :  */
   13124             : static char *
   13125        4102 : getFormattedOperatorName(const char *oproid)
   13126             : {
   13127             :     OprInfo    *oprInfo;
   13128             : 
   13129             :     /* In all cases "0" means a null reference */
   13130        4102 :     if (strcmp(oproid, "0") == 0)
   13131        2186 :         return NULL;
   13132             : 
   13133        1916 :     oprInfo = findOprByOid(atooid(oproid));
   13134        1916 :     if (oprInfo == NULL)
   13135             :     {
   13136           0 :         pg_log_warning("could not find operator with OID %s",
   13137             :                        oproid);
   13138           0 :         return NULL;
   13139             :     }
   13140             : 
   13141        1916 :     return psprintf("OPERATOR(%s.%s)",
   13142        1916 :                     fmtId(oprInfo->dobj.namespace->dobj.name),
   13143             :                     oprInfo->dobj.name);
   13144             : }
   13145             : 
   13146             : /*
   13147             :  * Convert a function OID obtained from pg_ts_parser or pg_ts_template
   13148             :  *
   13149             :  * It is sufficient to use REGPROC rather than REGPROCEDURE, since the
   13150             :  * argument lists of these functions are predetermined.  Note that the
   13151             :  * caller should ensure we are in the proper schema, because the results
   13152             :  * are search path dependent!
   13153             :  */
   13154             : static char *
   13155         330 : convertTSFunction(Archive *fout, Oid funcOid)
   13156             : {
   13157             :     char       *result;
   13158             :     char        query[128];
   13159             :     PGresult   *res;
   13160             : 
   13161         330 :     snprintf(query, sizeof(query),
   13162             :              "SELECT '%u'::pg_catalog.regproc", funcOid);
   13163         330 :     res = ExecuteSqlQueryForSingleRow(fout, query);
   13164             : 
   13165         330 :     result = pg_strdup(PQgetvalue(res, 0, 0));
   13166             : 
   13167         330 :     PQclear(res);
   13168             : 
   13169         330 :     return result;
   13170             : }
   13171             :

   13518             : /*
   13519             :  * dumpOpfamily
   13520             :  *    write out a single operator family definition

   14619             : static void

   14959             : 
   14960             : /*
   14961             :  * dumpUserMappings
   14962             :  *
   14963             :  * This routine is used to dump any user mappings associated with the
   14964             :  * server handed to this routine. Should be called after ArchiveEntry()
   14965             :  * for the server.
   14966             :  */
   14967             : static void
   14968          90 : dumpUserMappings(Archive *fout,
   14969             :                  const char *servername, const char *namespace,
   14970             :                  const char *owner,
   14971             :                  CatalogId catalogId, DumpId dumpId)
   14972             : {
   14973             :     PQExpBuffer q;
   14974             :     PQExpBuffer delq;
   14975             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   14976             :     PQExpBuffer tag;
   14977             :     PGresult   *res;
   14978             :     int         ntups;
   14979             :     int         i_usename;
   14980             :     int         i_umoptions;
   14981             :     int         i;
   14982             : 
   14983          90 :     q = createPQExpBuffer();
   14984          90 :     tag = createPQExpBuffer();
   14985          90 :     delq = createPQExpBuffer();
   14986          90 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   14987             : 
   14988             :     /*
   14989             :      * We read from the publicly accessible view pg_user_mappings, so as not
   14990             :      * to fail if run by a non-superuser.  Note that the view will show
   14991             :      * umoptions as null if the user hasn't got privileges for the associated
   14992             :      * server; this means that pg_dump will dump such a mapping, but with no
   14993             :      * OPTIONS clause.  A possible alternative is to skip such mappings
   14994             :      * altogether, but it's not clear that that's an improvement.
   14995             :      */
   14996          90 :     appendPQExpBuffer(query,
   14997             :                       "SELECT usename, "
   14998             :                       "array_to_string(ARRAY("
   14999             :                       "SELECT quote_ident(option_name) || ' ' || "
   15000             :                       "quote_literal(option_value) "
   15001             :                       "FROM pg_options_to_table(umoptions) "
   15002             :                       "ORDER BY option_name"
   15003             :                       "), E',\n    ') AS umoptions "
   15004             :                       "FROM pg_user_mappings "
   15005             :                       "WHERE srvid = '%u' "
   15006             :                       "ORDER BY usename",
   15007             :                       catalogId.oid);
   15008             : 
   15009          90 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   15010             : 
   15011          90 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   15012          90 :     i_usename = PQfnumber(res, "usename");
   15013          90 :     i_umoptions = PQfnumber(res, "umoptions");
   15014             : 
   15015         148 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
   15016             :     {
   15017             :         char       *usename;
   15018             :         char       *umoptions;
   15019             : 
   15020          58 :         usename = PQgetvalue(res, i, i_usename);
   15021          58 :         umoptions = PQgetvalue(res, i, i_umoptions);
   15022             : 
   15023          58 :         resetPQExpBuffer(q);
   15024          58 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, "CREATE USER MAPPING FOR %s", fmtId(usename));
   15025          58 :         appendPQExpBuffer(q, " SERVER %s", fmtId(servername));
   15026             : 
   15027          58 :         if (umoptions && strlen(umoptions) > 0)
   15028           0 :             appendPQExpBuffer(q, " OPTIONS (\n    %s\n)", umoptions);
   15029             : 
   15030          58 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ";\n");
   15031             : 
   15032          58 :         resetPQExpBuffer(delq);
   15033          58 :         appendPQExpBuffer(delq, "DROP USER MAPPING FOR %s", fmtId(usename));
   15034          58 :         appendPQExpBuffer(delq, " SERVER %s;\n", fmtId(servername));
   15035             : 
   15036          58 :         resetPQExpBuffer(tag);
   15037          58 :         appendPQExpBuffer(tag, "USER MAPPING %s SERVER %s",
   15038             :                           usename, servername);
   15039             : 
   15040          58 :         ArchiveEntry(fout, nilCatalogId, createDumpId(),
   15041          58 :                      ARCHIVE_OPTS(.tag = tag->data,
   15042             :                                   .namespace = namespace,
   15043             :                                   .owner = owner,
   15044             :                                   .description = "USER MAPPING",
   15045             :                                   .section = SECTION_PRE_DATA,
   15046             :                                   .createStmt = q->data,
   15047             :                                   .dropStmt = delq->data));
   15048             :     }
   15049             : 
   15050          90 :     PQclear(res);
   15051             : 
   15052          90 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
   15053          90 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(delq);
   15054          90 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(tag);
   15055          90 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(q);
   15056          90 : }
   15057             : 
   15058             : /*
   15059             :  * Write out default privileges information
   15060             :  */
   15061             : static void
   15062         260 : dumpDefaultACL(Archive *fout, const DefaultACLInfo *daclinfo)
   15063             : {
   15064         260 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   15065             :     PQExpBuffer q;
   15066             :     PQExpBuffer tag;
   15067             :     const char *type;
   15068             : 
   15069             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump, or if we're skipping ACLs */
   15070         260 :     if (dopt->dataOnly || dopt->aclsSkip)
   15071          32 :         return;
   15072             : 
   15073         228 :     q = createPQExpBuffer();
   15074         228 :     tag = createPQExpBuffer();
   15075             : 
   15076         228 :     switch (daclinfo->defaclobjtype)
   15077             :     {
   15078         114 :         case DEFACLOBJ_RELATION:
   15079         114 :             type = "TABLES";
   15080         114 :             break;
   15081           0 :         case DEFACLOBJ_SEQUENCE:
   15082           0 :             type = "SEQUENCES";
   15083           0 :             break;
   15084         114 :         case DEFACLOBJ_FUNCTION:
   15085         114 :             type = "FUNCTIONS";
   15086         114 :             break;
   15087           0 :         case DEFACLOBJ_TYPE:
   15088           0 :             type = "TYPES";
   15089           0 :             break;
   15090           0 :         case DEFACLOBJ_NAMESPACE:
   15091           0 :             type = "SCHEMAS";
   15092           0 :             break;
   15093           0 :         default:
   15094             :             /* shouldn't get here */
   15095           0 :             pg_fatal("unrecognized object type in default privileges: %d",
   15096             :                      (int) daclinfo->defaclobjtype);
   15097             :             type = "";            /* keep compiler quiet */
   15098             :     }
   15099             : 
   15100         228 :     appendPQExpBuffer(tag, "DEFAULT PRIVILEGES FOR %s", type);
   15101             : 
   15102             :     /* build the actual command(s) for this tuple */
   15103         228 :     if (!buildDefaultACLCommands(type,

   15126             : }
   15127             : 
   15128             : /*----------
   15129             :  * Write out grant/revoke information
   15130             :  *
   15131             :  * 'objDumpId' is the dump ID of the underlying object.
   15132             :  * 'altDumpId' can be a second dumpId that the ACL entry must also depend on,
   15133             :  *      or InvalidDumpId if there is no need for a second dependency.
   15134             :  * 'type' must be one of
   15135             :  *      TABLE, SEQUENCE, FUNCTION, LANGUAGE, SCHEMA, DATABASE, TABLESPACE,
   15136             :  *      FOREIGN DATA WRAPPER, SERVER, or LARGE OBJECT.
   15137             :  * 'name' is the formatted name of the object.  Must be quoted etc. already.
   15138             :  * 'subname' is the formatted name of the sub-object, if any.  Must be quoted.
   15139             :  *      (Currently we assume that subname is only provided for table columns.)
   15140             :  * 'nspname' is the namespace the object is in (NULL if none).
   15141             :  * 'owner' is the owner, NULL if there is no owner (for languages).
   15142             :  * 'dacl' is the DumpableAcl struct for the object.
   15143             :  *
   15144             :  * Returns the dump ID assigned to the ACL TocEntry, or InvalidDumpId if
   15145             :  * no ACL entry was created.
   15146             :  *----------
   15147             :  */
   15148             : static DumpId
   15149       43260 : dumpACL(Archive *fout, DumpId objDumpId, DumpId altDumpId,
   15150             :         const char *type, const char *name, const char *subname,
   15151             :         const char *nspname, const char *owner,
   15152             :         const DumpableAcl *dacl)
   15153             : {
   15154       43260 :     DumpId      aclDumpId = InvalidDumpId;
   15155       43260 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   15156       43260 :     const char *acls = dacl->acl;
   15157       43260 :     const char *acldefault = dacl->acldefault;
   15158       43260 :     char        privtype = dacl->privtype;
   15159       43260 :     const char *initprivs = dacl->initprivs;
   15160             :     const char *baseacls;
   15161             :     PQExpBuffer sql;
   15162             : 
   15163             :     /* Do nothing if ACL dump is not enabled */
   15164       43260 :     if (dopt->aclsSkip)
   15165         636 :         return InvalidDumpId;
   15166             : 
   15167             :     /* --data-only skips ACLs *except* large object ACLs */
   15168       42624 :     if (dopt->dataOnly && strcmp(type, "LARGE OBJECT") != 0)
   15169           0 :         return InvalidDumpId;
   15170             : 
   15171       42624 :     sql = createPQExpBuffer();
   15172             : 
   15173             :     /*
   15174             :      * In binary upgrade mode, we don't run an extension's script but instead
   15175             :      * dump out the objects independently and then recreate them.  To preserve
   15176             :      * any initial privileges which were set on extension objects, we need to
   15177             :      * compute the set of GRANT and REVOKE commands necessary to get from the
   15178             :      * default privileges of an object to its initial privileges as recorded
   15179             :      * in pg_init_privs.
   15180             :      *
   15181             :      * At restore time, we apply these commands after having called
   15182             :      * binary_upgrade_set_record_init_privs(true).  That tells the backend to
   15183             :      * copy the results into pg_init_privs.  This is how we preserve the
   15184             :      * contents of that catalog across binary upgrades.
   15185             :      */
   15186       42624 :     if (dopt->binary_upgrade && privtype == 'e' &&
   15187          26 :         initprivs && *initprivs != '\0')
   15188             :     {
   15189          26 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(sql, "SELECT pg_catalog.binary_upgrade_set_record_init_privs(true);\n");
   15190          26 :         if (!buildACLCommands(name, subname, nspname, type,
   15191             :                               initprivs, acldefault, owner,
   15192             :                               "", fout->remoteVersion, sql))
   15193           0 :             pg_fatal("could not parse initial ACL list (%s) or default (%s) for object \"%s\" (%s)",
   15194             :                      initprivs, acldefault, name, type);
   15195          26 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(sql, "SELECT pg_catalog.binary_upgrade_set_record_init_privs(false);\n");
   15196             :     }
   15197             : 
   15198             :     /*
   15199             :      * Now figure the GRANT and REVOKE commands needed to get to the object's
   15200             :      * actual current ACL, starting from the initprivs if given, else from the
   15201             :      * object-type-specific default.  Also, while buildACLCommands will assume
   15202             :      * that a NULL/empty acls string means it needn't do anything, what that
   15203             :      * actually represents is the object-type-specific default; so we need to
   15204             :      * substitute the acldefault string to get the right results in that case.
   15205             :      */
   15206       42624 :     if (initprivs && *initprivs != '\0')
   15207             :     {
   15208       39454 :         baseacls = initprivs;
   15209       39454 :         if (acls == NULL || *acls == '\0')
   15210          34 :             acls = acldefault;
   15211             :     }
   15212             :     else
   15213        3170 :         baseacls = acldefault;
   15214             : 
   15215       42624 :     if (!buildACLCommands(name, subname, nspname, type,
   15216             :                           acls, baseacls, owner,
   15217             :                           "", fout->remoteVersion, sql))
   15218           0 :         pg_fatal("could not parse ACL list (%s) or default (%s) for object \"%s\" (%s)",

   15220             : 
   15221       42624 :     if (sql->len > 0)
   15222             :     {
   15223        3320 :         PQExpBuffer tag = createPQExpBuffer();

   15227        3320 :         if (subname)
   15228        1954 :             appendPQExpBuffer(tag, "COLUMN %s.%s", name, subname);

   15230        1366 :             appendPQExpBuffer(tag, "%s %s", type, name);

   15255             : 
   15256             : /*
   15257             :  * dumpSecLabel
   15258             :  *
   15259             :  * This routine is used to dump any security labels associated with the
   15260             :  * object handed to this routine. The routine takes the object type
   15261             :  * and object name (ready to print, except for schema decoration), plus
   15262             :  * the namespace and owner of the object (for labeling the ArchiveEntry),
   15263             :  * plus catalog ID and subid which are the lookup key for pg_seclabel,
   15264             :  * plus the dump ID for the object (for setting a dependency).
   15265             :  * If a matching pg_seclabel entry is found, it is dumped.
   15266             :  *
   15267             :  * Note: although this routine takes a dumpId for dependency purposes,
   15268             :  * that purpose is just to mark the dependency in the emitted dump file
   15269             :  * for possible future use by pg_restore.  We do NOT use it for determining
   15270             :  * ordering of the label in the dump file, because this routine is called
   15271             :  * after dependency sorting occurs.  This routine should be called just after
   15272             :  * calling ArchiveEntry() for the specified object.
   15273             :  */

   15429             : /*
   15430             :  * findSecLabels
   15431             :  *
   15432             :  * Find the security label(s), if any, associated with the given object.
   15433             :  * All the objsubid values associated with the given classoid/objoid are
   15434             :  * found with one search.
   15435             :  */
   15436             : static int
   15437           0 : findSecLabels(Oid classoid, Oid objoid, SecLabelItem **items)
   15438             : {
   15439           0 :     SecLabelItem *middle = NULL;
   15440             :     SecLabelItem *low;
   15441             :     SecLabelItem *high;
   15442             :     int         nmatch;
   15443             : 
   15444           0 :     if (nseclabels <= 0)     /* no labels, so no match is possible */
   15445             :     {
   15446           0 :         *items = NULL;
   15447           0 :         return 0;
   15448             :     }
   15449             : 
   15450             :     /*
   15451             :      * Do binary search to find some item matching the object.
   15452             :      */
   15453           0 :     low = &seclabels[0];
   15454           0 :     high = &seclabels[nseclabels - 1];
   15455           0 :     while (low <= high)
   15456             :     {
   15457           0 :         middle = low + (high - low) / 2;
   15458             : 
   15459           0 :         if (classoid < middle->classoid)
   15460           0 :             high = middle - 1;
   15461           0 :         else if (classoid > middle->classoid)
   15462           0 :             low = middle + 1;
   15463           0 :         else if (objoid < middle->objoid)
   15464           0 :             high = middle - 1;
   15465           0 :         else if (objoid > middle->objoid)
   15466           0 :             low = middle + 1;
   15467             :         else
   15468           0 :             break;              /* found a match */
   15469             :     }
   15470             : 
   15471           0 :     if (low > high)              /* no matches */
   15472             :     {
   15473           0 :         *items = NULL;
   15474           0 :         return 0;
   15475             :     }
   15476             : 
   15477             :     /*
   15478             :      * Now determine how many items match the object.  The search loop
   15479             :      * invariant still holds: only items between low and high inclusive could
   15480             :      * match.
   15481             :      */

   15483           0 :     while (middle > low)
   15484             :     {
   15485           0 :         if (classoid != middle[-1].classoid ||
   15486           0 :             objoid != middle[-1].objoid)
   15487             :             break;

   15489           0 :         nmatch++;
   15490             :     }
   15491             : 
   15492           0 :     *items = middle;
   15493             : 
   15494           0 :     middle += nmatch;
   15495           0 :     while (middle <= high)
   15496             :     {
   15497           0 :         if (classoid != middle->classoid ||
   15498           0 :             objoid != middle->objoid)
   15499             :             break;
   15500           0 :         middle++;
   15501           0 :         nmatch++;
   15502             :     }
   15503             : 
   15504           0 :     return nmatch;
   15505             : }
   15506             : 
   15507             : /*
   15508             :  * collectSecLabels
   15509             :  *
   15510             :  * Construct a table of all security labels available for database objects;
   15511             :  * also set the has-seclabel component flag for each relevant object.
   15512             :  *
   15513             :  * The table is sorted by classoid/objid/objsubid for speed in lookup.
   15514             :  */
   15515             : static void
   15516         294 : collectSecLabels(Archive *fout)
   15517             : {
   15518             :     PGresult   *res;
   15519             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   15520             :     int         i_label;
   15521             :     int         i_provider;
   15522             :     int         i_classoid;
   15523             :     int         i_objoid;
   15524             :     int         i_objsubid;
   15525             :     int         ntups;
   15526             :     int         i;
   15527             :     DumpableObject *dobj;
   15528             : 
   15529         294 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   15530             : 
   15531         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
   15532             :                          "SELECT label, provider, classoid, objoid, objsubid "
   15533             :                          "FROM pg_catalog.pg_seclabel "
   15534             :                          "ORDER BY classoid, objoid, objsubid");
   15535             : 
   15536         294 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   15537             : 
   15538             :     /* Construct lookup table containing OIDs in numeric form */
   15539         294 :     i_label = PQfnumber(res, "label");
   15540         294 :     i_provider = PQfnumber(res, "provider");
   15541         294 :     i_classoid = PQfnumber(res, "classoid");
   15542         294 :     i_objoid = PQfnumber(res, "objoid");
   15543         294 :     i_objsubid = PQfnumber(res, "objsubid");
   15544             : 
   15545         294 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   15546             : 
   15547         294 :     seclabels = (SecLabelItem *) pg_malloc(ntups * sizeof(SecLabelItem));
   15548         294 :     nseclabels = 0;
   15549         294 :     dobj = NULL;
   15550             : 
   15551         294 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
   15552             :     {
   15553             :         CatalogId   objId;
   15554             :         int         subid;
   15555             : 
   15556           0 :         objId.tableoid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_classoid));
   15557           0 :         objId.oid = atooid(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_objoid));
   15558           0 :         subid = atoi(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_objsubid));
   15559             : 
   15560             :         /* We needn't remember labels that don't match any dumpable object */
   15561           0 :         if (dobj == NULL ||
   15562           0 :             dobj->catId.tableoid != objId.tableoid ||
   15563           0 :             dobj->catId.oid != objId.oid)
   15564           0 :             dobj = findObjectByCatalogId(objId);
   15565           0 :         if (dobj == NULL)
   15566           0 :             continue;
   15567             : 
   15568             :         /*
   15569             :          * Labels on columns of composite types are linked to the type's
   15570             :          * pg_class entry, but we need to set the DUMP_COMPONENT_SECLABEL flag
   15571             :          * in the type's own DumpableObject.
   15572             :          */
   15573           0 :         if (subid != 0 && dobj->objType == DO_TABLE &&
   15574           0 :             ((TableInfo *) dobj)->relkind == RELKIND_COMPOSITE_TYPE)

   15584             : 
   15585           0 :         seclabels[nseclabels].label = pg_strdup(PQgetvalue(res, i, i_label));

   15587           0 :         seclabels[nseclabels].classoid = objId.tableoid;
   15588           0 :         seclabels[nseclabels].objoid = objId.oid;
   15589           0 :         seclabels[nseclabels].objsubid = subid;
   15590           0 :         nseclabels++;
   15591             :     }
   15592             : 
   15593         294 :     PQclear(res);
   15594         294 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
   15595         294 : }
   15596             : 
   15597             : /*
   15598             :  * dumpTable
   15599             :  *    write out to fout the declarations (not data) of a user-defined table
   15600             :  */
   15601             : static void
   15602       47184 : dumpTable(Archive *fout, const TableInfo *tbinfo)
   15603             : {
   15604       47184 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   15605       47184 :     DumpId      tableAclDumpId = InvalidDumpId;
   15606             :     char       *namecopy;
   15607             : 
   15608             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump */
   15609       47184 :     if (dopt->dataOnly)
   15610        1704 :         return;
   15611             : 
   15612       45480 :     if (tbinfo->dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION)
   15613             :     {
   15614       10526 :         if (tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_SEQUENCE)
   15615         698 :             dumpSequence(fout, tbinfo);
   15616             :         else
   15617        9828 :             dumpTableSchema(fout, tbinfo);
   15618             :     }
   15619             : 
   15620             :     /* Handle the ACL here */

   15630       35776 :                     tbinfo->dobj.namespace->dobj.name, tbinfo->rolname,
   15631             :                     &tbinfo->dacl);
   15632             :     }
   15633             : 
   15634             :     /*
   15635             :      * Handle column ACLs, if any.  Note: we pull these with a separate query
   15636             :      * rather than trying to fetch them during getTableAttrs, so that we won't
   15637             :      * miss ACLs on system columns.  Doing it this way also allows us to dump
   15638             :      * ACLs for catalogs that we didn't mark "interesting" back in getTables.
   15639             :      */
   15640       45480 :     if ((tbinfo->dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENT_ACL) && tbinfo->hascolumnACLs)
   15641             :     {
   15642         470 :         PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
   15643             :         PGresult   *res;
   15644             :         int         i;
   15645             : 
   15646         470 :         if (!fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_GETCOLUMNACLS])
   15647             :         {
   15648             :             /* Set up query for column ACLs */
   15649         248 :             appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
   15650             :                                  "PREPARE getColumnACLs(pg_catalog.oid) AS\n");
   15651             : 
   15652         248 :             if (fout->remoteVersion >= 90600)
   15653             :             {
   15654             :                 /*
   15655             :                  * In principle we should call acldefault('c', relowner) to
   15656             :                  * get the default ACL for a column.  However, we don't
   15657             :                  * currently store the numeric OID of the relowner in
   15658             :                  * TableInfo.  We could convert the owner name using regrole,
   15659             :                  * but that creates a risk of failure due to concurrent role
   15660             :                  * renames.  Given that the default ACL for columns is empty
   15661             :                  * and is likely to stay that way, it's not worth extra cycles
   15662             :                  * and risk to avoid hard-wiring that knowledge here.
   15663             :                  */
   15664         248 :                 appendPQExpBufferStr(query,
   15665             :                                      "SELECT at.attname, "
   15666             :                                      "at.attacl, "
   15667             :                                      "'{}' AS acldefault, "
   15668             :                                      "pip.privtype, pip.initprivs "
   15669             :                                      "FROM pg_catalog.pg_attribute at "
   15670             :                                      "LEFT JOIN pg_catalog.pg_init_privs pip ON "
   15671             :                                      "(at.attrelid = pip.objoid "
   15672             :                                      "AND pip.classoid = 'pg_catalog.pg_class'::pg_catalog.regclass "
   15673             :                                      "AND at.attnum = pip.objsubid) "
   15674             :                                      "WHERE at.attrelid = $1 AND "
   15675             :                                      "NOT at.attisdropped "
   15676             :                                      "AND (at.attacl IS NOT NULL OR pip.initprivs IS NOT NULL) "
   15677             :                                      "ORDER BY at.attnum");

   15679             :             else

   15684             :                                      "FROM pg_catalog.pg_attribute "
   15685             :                                      "WHERE attrelid = $1 AND NOT attisdropped "
   15686             :                                      "AND attacl IS NOT NULL "

   15695         470 :         printfPQExpBuffer(query,

   15699         470 :         res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);

   15701        6538 :         for (i = 0; i < PQntuples(res); i++)

   15734             : 
   15735             : /*
   15736             :  * Create the AS clause for a view or materialized view. The semicolon is
   15737             :  * stripped because a materialized view must add a WITH NO DATA clause.
   15738             :  *
   15739             :  * This returns a new buffer which must be freed by the caller.
   15740             :  */
   15741             : static PQExpBuffer
   15742        1236 : createViewAsClause(Archive *fout, const TableInfo *tbinfo)
   15743             : {
   15744        1236 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
   15745        1236 :     PQExpBuffer result = createPQExpBuffer();
   15746             :     PGresult   *res;
   15747             :     int         len;
   15748             : 
   15749             :     /* Fetch the view definition */
   15750        1236 :     appendPQExpBuffer(query,
   15751             :                       "SELECT pg_catalog.pg_get_viewdef('%u'::pg_catalog.oid) AS viewdef",
   15752        1236 :                       tbinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
   15753             : 
   15754        1236 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   15755             : 
   15756        1236 :     if (PQntuples(res) != 1)
   15757             :     {
   15758           0 :         if (PQntuples(res) < 1)
   15759           0 :             pg_fatal("query to obtain definition of view \"%s\" returned no data",
   15760             :                      tbinfo->dobj.name);
   15761             :         else
   15762           0 :             pg_fatal("query to obtain definition of view \"%s\" returned more than one definition",
   15763             :                      tbinfo->dobj.name);
   15764             :     }
   15765             : 
   15766        1236 :     len = PQgetlength(res, 0, 0);
   15767             : 
   15768        1236 :     if (len == 0)
   15769           0 :         pg_fatal("definition of view \"%s\" appears to be empty (length zero)",
   15770             :                  tbinfo->dobj.name);
   15771             : 
   15772             :     /* Strip off the trailing semicolon so that other things may follow. */
   15773        1236 :     Assert(PQgetvalue(res, 0, 0)[len - 1] == ';');
   15774        1236 :     appendBinaryPQExpBuffer(result, PQgetvalue(res, 0, 0), len - 1);
   15775             : 
   15776        1236 :     PQclear(res);
   15777        1236 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(query);
   15778             : 
   15779        1236 :     return result;
   15780             : }
   15781             : 
   15782             : /*
   15783             :  * Create a dummy AS clause for a view.  This is used when the real view
   15784             :  * definition has to be postponed because of circular dependencies.
   15785             :  * We must duplicate the view's external properties -- column names and types
   15786             :  * (including collation) -- so that it works for subsequent references.
   15787             :  *
   15788             :  * This returns a new buffer which must be freed by the caller.
   15789             :  */
   15790             : static PQExpBuffer
   15791          40 : createDummyViewAsClause(Archive *fout, const TableInfo *tbinfo)
   15792             : {
   15793          40 :     PQExpBuffer result = createPQExpBuffer();
   15794             :     int         j;
   15795             : 
   15796          40 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(result, "SELECT");
   15797             : 
   15798          80 :     for (j = 0; j < tbinfo->numatts; j++)
   15799             :     {
   15800          40 :         if (j > 0)
   15801          20 :             appendPQExpBufferChar(result, ',');
   15802          40 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(result, "\n    ");
   15803             : 
   15804          40 :         appendPQExpBuffer(result, "NULL::%s", tbinfo->atttypnames[j]);
   15805             : 
   15806             :         /*
   15807             :          * Must add collation if not default for the type, because CREATE OR
   15808             :          * REPLACE VIEW won't change it
   15809             :          */
   15810          40 :         if (OidIsValid(tbinfo->attcollation[j]))
   15811             :         {
   15812             :             CollInfo   *coll;
   15813             : 
   15814           0 :             coll = findCollationByOid(tbinfo->attcollation[j]);
   15815           0 :             if (coll)
   15816           0 :                 appendPQExpBuffer(result, " COLLATE %s",
   15817           0 :                                   fmtQualifiedDumpable(coll));
   15818             :         }
   15819             : 
   15820          40 :         appendPQExpBuffer(result, " AS %s", fmtId(tbinfo->attnames[j]));
   15821             :     }
   15822             : 
   15823          40 :     return result;
   15824             : }
   15825             : 
   15826             : /*
   15827             :  * dumpTableSchema
   15828             :  *    write the declaration (not data) of one user-defined table or view

   15830             : static void
   15831        9828 : dumpTableSchema(Archive *fout, const TableInfo *tbinfo)
   15832             : {
   15833        9828 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   15834        9828 :     PQExpBuffer q = createPQExpBuffer();

   15837             :     char       *qualrelname;
   15838             :     int         numParents;
   15839             :     TableInfo **parents;
   15840             :     int         actual_atts;    /* number of attrs in this CREATE statement */

   15842             :     char       *storage;

   15844             :                 k;
   15845             :

   16239           4 :                     appendPQExpBufferStr(q, ");\n\n");
   16240             :                 }
   16241             :             }
   16242             :         }
   16243             : 
   16244             :         /*
   16245             :          * To create binary-compatible heap files, we have to ensure the same
   16246             :          * physical column order, including dropped columns, as in the
   16247             :          * original.  Therefore, we create dropped columns above and drop them
   16248             :          * here, also updating their attlen/attalign values so that the
   16249             :          * dropped column can be skipped properly.  (We do not bother with
   16250             :          * restoring the original attbyval setting.)  Also, inheritance
   16251             :          * relationships are set up by doing ALTER TABLE INHERIT rather than
   16252             :          * using an INHERITS clause --- the latter would possibly mess up the
   16253             :          * column order.  That also means we have to take care about setting
   16254             :          * attislocal correctly, plus fix up any inherited CHECK constraints.
   16255             :          * Analogously, we set up typed tables using ALTER TABLE / OF here.
   16256             :          *
   16257             :          * We process foreign and partitioned tables here, even though they
   16258             :          * lack heap storage, because they can participate in inheritance
   16259             :          * relationships and we want this stuff to be consistent across the
   16260             :          * inheritance tree.  We can exclude indexes, toast tables, sequences
   16261             :          * and matviews, even though they have storage, because we don't
   16262             :          * support altering or dropping columns in them, nor can they be part
   16263             :          * of inheritance trees.
   16264             :          */
   16265        9142 :         if (dopt->binary_upgrade &&
   16266        1378 :             (tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_RELATION ||
   16267         194 :              tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_FOREIGN_TABLE ||
   16268         192 :              tbinfo->relkind == RELKIND_PARTITIONED_TABLE))
   16269             :         {
   16270        7130 :             for (j = 0; j < tbinfo->numatts; j++)
   16271             :             {
   16272        5782 :                 if (tbinfo->attisdropped[j])
   16273             :                 {
   16274         158 :                     appendPQExpBufferStr(q, "\n-- For binary upgrade, recreate dropped column.\n");

   16277             :                                       "attalign = '%c', attbyval = false\n"
   16278             :                                       "WHERE attname = ",
   16279         158 :                                       tbinfo->attlen[j],
   16280         158 :                                       tbinfo->attalign[j]);
   16281         158 :                     appendStringLiteralAH(q, tbinfo->attnames[j], fout);

   16652             : 
   16653             : /*
   16654             :  * dumpTableAttach
   16655             :  *    write to fout the commands to attach a child partition
   16656             :  *
   16657             :  * Child partitions are always made by creating them separately
   16658             :  * and then using ATTACH PARTITION, rather than using
   16659             :  * CREATE TABLE ... PARTITION OF.  This is important for preserving
   16660             :  * any possible discrepancy in column layout, to allow assigning the
   16661             :  * correct tablespace if different, and so that it's possible to restore
   16662             :  * a partition without restoring its parent.  (You'll get an error from
   16663             :  * the ATTACH PARTITION command, but that can be ignored, or skipped
   16664             :  * using "pg_restore -L" if you prefer.)  The last point motivates
   16665             :  * treating ATTACH PARTITION as a completely separate ArchiveEntry
   16666             :  * rather than emitting it within the child partition's ArchiveEntry.
   16667             :  */
   16668             : static void
   16669        2282 : dumpTableAttach(Archive *fout, const TableAttachInfo *attachinfo)
   16670             : {
   16671        2282 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   16672             :     PQExpBuffer q;
   16673             :     PGresult   *res;
   16674             :     char       *partbound;
   16675             : 
   16676             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump */
   16677        2282 :     if (dopt->dataOnly)
   16678          30 :         return;
   16679             : 
   16680        2252 :     q = createPQExpBuffer();
   16681             : 
   16682        2252 :     if (!fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_DUMPTABLEATTACH])
   16683             :     {
   16684             :         /* Set up query for partbound details */
   16685          82 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
   16686             :                              "PREPARE dumpTableAttach(pg_catalog.oid) AS\n");
   16687             : 
   16688          82 :         appendPQExpBufferStr(q,
   16689             :                              "SELECT pg_get_expr(c.relpartbound, c.oid) "
   16690             :                              "FROM pg_class c "
   16691             :                              "WHERE c.oid = $1");
   16692             : 
   16693          82 :         ExecuteSqlStatement(fout, q->data);
   16694             : 
   16695          82 :         fout->is_prepared[PREPQUERY_DUMPTABLEATTACH] = true;
   16696             :     }
   16697             : 
   16698        2252 :     printfPQExpBuffer(q,
   16699             :                       "EXECUTE dumpTableAttach('%u')",
   16700        2252 :                       attachinfo->partitionTbl->dobj.catId.oid);
   16701             : 
   16702        2252 :     res = ExecuteSqlQueryForSingleRow(fout, q->data);
   16703        2252 :     partbound = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 0);
   16704             : 
   16705             :     /* Perform ALTER TABLE on the parent */
   16706        2252 :     printfPQExpBuffer(q,
   16707             :                       "ALTER TABLE ONLY %s ",
   16708        2252 :                       fmtQualifiedDumpable(attachinfo->parentTbl));
   16709        2252 :     appendPQExpBuffer(q,
   16710             :                       "ATTACH PARTITION %s %s;\n",
   16711        2252 :                       fmtQualifiedDumpable(attachinfo->partitionTbl),
   16712             :                       partbound);
   16713             : 
   16714             :     /*
   16715             :      * There is no point in creating a drop query as the drop is done by table
   16716             :      * drop.  (If you think to change this, see also _printTocEntry().)
   16717             :      * Although this object doesn't really have ownership as such, set the
   16718             :      * owner field anyway to ensure that the command is run by the correct
   16719             :      * role at restore time.
   16720             :      */
   16721        2252 :     ArchiveEntry(fout, attachinfo->dobj.catId, attachinfo->dobj.dumpId,
   16722        2252 :                  ARCHIVE_OPTS(.tag = attachinfo->dobj.name,
   16723             :                               .namespace = attachinfo->dobj.namespace->dobj.name,
   16724             :                               .owner = attachinfo->partitionTbl->rolname,
   16725             :                               .description = "TABLE ATTACH",
   16726             :                               .section = SECTION_PRE_DATA,
   16727             :                               .createStmt = q->data));
   16728             : 
   16729        2252 :     PQclear(res);
   16730        2252 :     destroyPQExpBuffer(q);
   16731             : }
   16732             :

   16790             : /*
   16791             :  * getAttrName: extract the correct name for an attribute
   16792             :  *
   16793             :  * The array tblInfo->attnames[] only provides names of user attributes;
   16794             :  * if a system attribute number is supplied, we have to fake it.
   16795             :  * We also do a little bit of bounds checking for safety's sake.
   16796             :  */
   16797             : static const char *
   16798        2944 : getAttrName(int attrnum, const TableInfo *tblInfo)
   16799             : {
   16800        2944 :     if (attrnum > 0 && attrnum <= tblInfo->numatts)
   16801        2944 :         return tblInfo->attnames[attrnum - 1];

   16803             :     {
   16804           0 :         case SelfItemPointerAttributeNumber:
   16805           0 :             return "ctid";
   16806           0 :         case MinTransactionIdAttributeNumber:
   16807           0 :             return "xmin";
   16808           0 :         case MinCommandIdAttributeNumber:
   16809           0 :             return "cmin";
   16810           0 :         case MaxTransactionIdAttributeNumber:
   16811           0 :             return "xmax";
   16812           0 :         case MaxCommandIdAttributeNumber:
   16813           0 :             return "cmax";
   16814           0 :         case TableOidAttributeNumber:
   16815           0 :             return "tableoid";
   16816             :     }
   16817           0 :     pg_fatal("invalid column number %d for table \"%s\"",
   16818             :              attrnum, tblInfo->dobj.name);

   17016             :

   17020             :

   17023         218 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   17024             : 
   17025         218 :     qstatsextname = pg_strdup(fmtId(statsextinfo->dobj.name));
   17026             : 
   17027         218 :     appendPQExpBuffer(query, "SELECT "
   17028             :                       "pg_catalog.pg_get_statisticsobjdef('%u'::pg_catalog.oid)",
   17029         218 :                       statsextinfo->dobj.catId.oid);

   17036         218 :     appendPQExpBuffer(q, "%s;\n", stxdef);

   17080             : /*
   17081             :  * dumpConstraint
   17082             :  *    write out to fout a user-defined constraint
   17083             :  */

   17085        3602 : dumpConstraint(Archive *fout, const ConstraintInfo *coninfo)
   17086             : {
   17087        3602 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;

   17091        3602 :     char       *tag = NULL;

   17404             : /*
   17405             :  * dumpSequence
   17406             :  *    write the declaration (not data) of one user-defined sequence
   17407             :  */
   17408             : static void
   17409         698 : dumpSequence(Archive *fout, const TableInfo *tbinfo)
   17410             : {
   17411         698 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   17412             :     PGresult   *res;
   17413             :     char       *startv,
   17414             :                *incby,
   17415             :                *maxv,
   17416             :                *minv,
   17417             :                *cache,
   17418             :                *seqtype;
   17419             :     bool        cycled;
   17420             :     bool        is_ascending;
   17421             :     int64       default_minv,
   17422             :                 default_maxv;
   17423             :     char        bufm[32],
   17424             :                 bufx[32];
   17425         698 :     PQExpBuffer query = createPQExpBuffer();
   17426         698 :     PQExpBuffer delqry = createPQExpBuffer();
   17427             :     char       *qseqname;
   17428         698 :     TableInfo  *owning_tab = NULL;
   17429             : 
   17430         698 :     qseqname = pg_strdup(fmtId(tbinfo->dobj.name));
   17431             : 
   17432         698 :     if (fout->remoteVersion >= 100000)
   17433             :     {
   17434         698 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
   17435             :                           "SELECT format_type(seqtypid, NULL), "
   17436             :                           "seqstart, seqincrement, "
   17437             :                           "seqmax, seqmin, "
   17438             :                           "seqcache, seqcycle "
   17439             :                           "FROM pg_catalog.pg_sequence "
   17440             :                           "WHERE seqrelid = '%u'::oid",
   17441         698 :                           tbinfo->dobj.catId.oid);
   17442             :     }
   17443             :     else
   17444             :     {
   17445             :         /*
   17446             :          * Before PostgreSQL 10, sequence metadata is in the sequence itself.
   17447             :          *
   17448             :          * Note: it might seem that 'bigint' potentially needs to be
   17449             :          * schema-qualified, but actually that's a keyword.
   17450             :          */
   17451           0 :         appendPQExpBuffer(query,
   17452             :                           "SELECT 'bigint' AS sequence_type, "
   17453             :                           "start_value, increment_by, max_value, min_value, "
   17454             :                           "cache_value, is_cycled FROM %s",
   17455           0 :                           fmtQualifiedDumpable(tbinfo));
   17456             :     }
   17457             : 
   17458         698 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   17459             : 
   17460         698 :     if (PQntuples(res) != 1)
   17461           0 :         pg_fatal(ngettext("query to get data of sequence \"%s\" returned %d row (expected 1)",

   17463             :                           PQntuples(res)),
   17464             :                  tbinfo->dobj.name, PQntuples(res));
   17465             : 
   17466         698 :     seqtype = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 0);
   17467         698 :     startv = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 1);
   17468         698 :     incby = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 2);
   17469         698 :     maxv = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 3);
   17470         698 :     minv = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 4);
   17471         698 :     cache = PQgetvalue(res, 0, 5);
   17472         698 :     cycled = (strcmp(PQgetvalue(res, 0, 6), "t") == 0);
   17473             : 
   17474             :     /* Calculate default limits for a sequence of this type */
   17475         698 :     is_ascending = (incby[0] != '-');
   17476         698 :     if (strcmp(seqtype, "smallint") == 0)
   17477             :     {
   17478          50 :         default_minv = is_ascending ? 1 : PG_INT16_MIN;
   17479          50 :         default_maxv = is_ascending ? PG_INT16_MAX : -1;
   17480             :     }
   17481         648 :     else if (strcmp(seqtype, "integer") == 0)
   17482             :     {
   17483         536 :         default_minv = is_ascending ? 1 : PG_INT32_MIN;
   17484         536 :         default_maxv = is_ascending ? PG_INT32_MAX : -1;
   17485             :     }
   17486         112 :     else if (strcmp(seqtype, "bigint") == 0)
   17487             :     {
   17488         112 :         default_minv = is_ascending ? 1 : PG_INT64_MIN;
   17489         112 :         default_maxv = is_ascending ? PG_INT64_MAX : -1;
   17490             :     }
   17491             :     else
   17492             :     {
   17493           0 :         pg_fatal("unrecognized sequence type: %s", seqtype);
   17494             :         default_minv = default_maxv = 0;    /* keep compiler quiet */
   17495             :     }
   17496             : 
   17497             :     /*
   17498             :      * 64-bit strtol() isn't very portable, so convert the limits to strings
   17499             :      * and compare that way.
   17500             :      */
   17501         698 :     snprintf(bufm, sizeof(bufm), INT64_FORMAT, default_minv);
   17502         698 :     snprintf(bufx, sizeof(bufx), INT64_FORMAT, default_maxv);

   17504             :     /* Don't print minv/maxv if they match the respective default limit */

   17506         668 :         minv = NULL;
   17507         698 :     if (strcmp(maxv, bufx) == 0)
   17508         668 :         maxv = NULL;

   17510             :     /*
   17511             :      * Identity sequences are not to be dropped separately.
   17512             :      */

   17609             :     /*
   17610             :      * If the sequence is owned by a table column, emit the ALTER for it as a
   17611             :      * separate TOC entry immediately following the sequence's own entry. It's
   17612             :      * OK to do this rather than using full sorting logic, because the
   17613             :      * dependency that tells us it's owned will have forced the table to be
   17614             :      * created first.  We can't just include the ALTER in the TOC entry
   17615             :      * because it will fail if we haven't reassigned the sequence owner to
   17616             :      * match the table's owner.
   17617             :      *

   17619             :      * and table must be in the same schema.

   17931             : /*
   17932             :  * dumpRule
   17933             :  *      Dump a rule
   17934             :  */
   17935             : static void
   17936        1684 : dumpRule(Archive *fout, const RuleInfo *rinfo)
   17937             : {
   17938        1684 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   17939        1684 :     TableInfo  *tbinfo = rinfo->ruletable;
   17940             :     bool        is_view;
   17941             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   17942             :     PQExpBuffer cmd;
   17943             :     PQExpBuffer delcmd;
   17944             :     PQExpBuffer ruleprefix;
   17945             :     char       *qtabname;
   17946             :     PGresult   *res;
   17947             :     char       *tag;
   17948             : 
   17949             :     /* Do nothing in data-only dump */
   17950        1684 :     if (dopt->dataOnly)
   17951          54 :         return;
   17952             : 
   17953             :     /*
   17954             :      * If it is an ON SELECT rule that is created implicitly by CREATE VIEW,
   17955             :      * we do not want to dump it as a separate object.
   17956             :      */
   17957        1630 :     if (!rinfo->separate)

   18091             : 
   18092             : /*
   18093             :  * getExtensionMembership --- obtain extension membership data
   18094             :  *
   18095             :  * We need to identify objects that are extension members as soon as they're
   18096             :  * loaded, so that we can correctly determine whether they need to be dumped.
   18097             :  * Generally speaking, extension member objects will get marked as *not* to
   18098             :  * be dumped, as they will be recreated by the single CREATE EXTENSION
   18099             :  * command.  However, in binary upgrade mode we still need to dump the members
   18100             :  * individually.
   18101             :  */
   18102             : void
   18103         296 : getExtensionMembership(Archive *fout, ExtensionInfo extinfo[],
   18104             :                        int numExtensions)
   18105             : {
   18106             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   18107             :     PGresult   *res;
   18108             :     int         ntups,
   18109             :                 i;
   18110             :     int         i_classid,
   18111             :                 i_objid,
   18112             :                 i_refobjid;
   18113             :     ExtensionInfo *ext;
   18114             : 
   18115             :     /* Nothing to do if no extensions */
   18116         296 :     if (numExtensions == 0)
   18117           0 :         return;
   18118             : 
   18119         296 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   18120             : 
   18121             :     /* refclassid constraint is redundant but may speed the search */
   18122         296 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT "
   18123             :                          "classid, objid, refobjid "
   18124             :                          "FROM pg_depend "
   18125             :                          "WHERE refclassid = 'pg_extension'::regclass "
   18126             :                          "AND deptype = 'e' "
   18127             :                          "ORDER BY 3");
   18128             : 
   18129         296 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   18130             : 
   18131         296 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   18132             :

   18134         296 :     i_objid = PQfnumber(res, "objid");
   18135         296 :     i_refobjid = PQfnumber(res, "refobjid");
   18136             : 
   18137             :     /*
   18138             :      * Since we ordered the SELECT by referenced ID, we can expect that
   18139             :      * multiple entries for the same extension will appear together; this

   18143             :

   18171             : 
   18172             : /*
   18173             :  * processExtensionTables --- deal with extension configuration tables
   18174             :  *
   18175             :  * There are two parts to this process:
   18176             :  *
   18177             :  * 1. Identify and create dump records for extension configuration tables.
   18178             :  *
   18179             :  *    Extensions can mark tables as "configuration", which means that the user
   18180             :  *    is able and expected to modify those tables after the extension has been
   18181             :  *    loaded.  For these tables, we dump out only the data- the structure is
   18182             :  *    expected to be handled at CREATE EXTENSION time, including any indexes or
   18183             :  *    foreign keys, which brings us to-
   18184             :  *
   18185             :  * 2. Record FK dependencies between configuration tables.
   18186             :  *
   18187             :  *    Due to the FKs being created at CREATE EXTENSION time and therefore before
   18188             :  *    the data is loaded, we have to work out what the best order for reloading
   18189             :  *    the data is, to avoid FK violations when the tables are restored.  This is
   18190             :  *    not perfect- we can't handle circular dependencies and if any exist they
   18191             :  *    will cause an invalid dump to be produced (though at least all of the data
   18192             :  *    is included for a user to manually restore).  This is currently documented
   18193             :  *    but perhaps we can provide a better solution in the future.
   18194             :  */
   18195             : void
   18196         294 : processExtensionTables(Archive *fout, ExtensionInfo extinfo[],
   18197             :                        int numExtensions)
   18198             : {
   18199         294 :     DumpOptions *dopt = fout->dopt;
   18200             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   18201             :     PGresult   *res;
   18202             :     int         ntups,
   18203             :                 i;
   18204             :     int         i_conrelid,
   18205             :                 i_confrelid;
   18206             : 
   18207             :     /* Nothing to do if no extensions */
   18208         294 :     if (numExtensions == 0)
   18209           0 :         return;
   18210             : 
   18211             :     /*
   18212             :      * Identify extension configuration tables and create TableDataInfo
   18213             :      * objects for them, ensuring their data will be dumped even though the
   18214             :      * tables themselves won't be.
   18215             :      *
   18216             :      * Note that we create TableDataInfo objects even in schemaOnly mode, ie,
   18217             :      * user data in a configuration table is treated like schema data. This
   18218             :      * seems appropriate since system data in a config table would get
   18219             :      * reloaded by CREATE EXTENSION.  If the extension is not listed in the
   18220             :      * list of extensions to be included, none of its data is dumped.
   18221             :      */
   18222         634 :     for (i = 0; i < numExtensions; i++)
   18223             :     {
   18224         340 :         ExtensionInfo *curext = &(extinfo[i]);
   18225         340 :         char       *extconfig = curext->extconfig;
   18226         340 :         char       *extcondition = curext->extcondition;
   18227         340 :         char      **extconfigarray = NULL;
   18228         340 :         char      **extconditionarray = NULL;
   18229         340 :         int         nconfigitems = 0;
   18230         340 :         int         nconditionitems = 0;
   18231             : 
   18232             :         /*
   18233             :          * Check if this extension is listed as to include in the dump.  If
   18234             :          * not, any table data associated with it is discarded.
   18235             :          */
   18236         340 :         if (extension_include_oids.head != NULL &&
   18237          16 :             !simple_oid_list_member(&extension_include_oids,
   18238             :                                     curext->dobj.catId.oid))
   18239           8 :             continue;
   18240             :

   18242             :         {

   18244             : 
   18245          40 :             if (!parsePGArray(extconfig, &extconfigarray, &nconfigitems))
   18246           0 :                 pg_fatal("could not parse %s array", "extconfig");
   18247          40 :             if (!parsePGArray(extcondition, &extconditionarray, &nconditionitems))
   18248           0 :                 pg_fatal("could not parse %s array", "extcondition");
   18249          40 :             if (nconfigitems != nconditionitems)
   18250           0 :                 pg_fatal("mismatched number of configurations and conditions for extension");

   18252         120 :             for (j = 0; j < nconfigitems; j++)
   18253             :             {
   18254             :                 TableInfo  *configtbl;
   18255          80 :                 Oid         configtbloid = atooid(extconfigarray[j]);
   18256          80 :                 bool        dumpobj =
   18257          80 :                     curext->dobj.dump & DUMP_COMPONENT_DEFINITION;

   18259          80 :                 configtbl = findTableByOid(configtbloid);
   18260          80 :                 if (configtbl == NULL)
   18261           0 :                     continue;

   18309             :     /*
   18310             :      * Now that all the TableDataInfo objects have been created for all the
   18311             :      * extensions, check their FK dependencies and register them to try and
   18312             :      * dump the data out in an order that they can be restored in.
   18313             :      *
   18314             :      * Note that this is not a problem for user tables as their FKs are
   18315             :      * recreated after the data has been loaded.

   18363             : 
   18364             : /*
   18365             :  * getDependencies --- obtain available dependency data
   18366             :  */
   18367             : static void
   18368         294 : getDependencies(Archive *fout)
   18369             : {
   18370             :     PQExpBuffer query;
   18371             :     PGresult   *res;
   18372             :     int         ntups,
   18373             :                 i;
   18374             :     int         i_classid,
   18375             :                 i_objid,
   18376             :                 i_refclassid,
   18377             :                 i_refobjid,
   18378             :                 i_deptype;
   18379             :     DumpableObject *dobj,
   18380             :                *refdobj;
   18381             : 
   18382         294 :     pg_log_info("reading dependency data");
   18383             : 
   18384         294 :     query = createPQExpBuffer();
   18385             : 
   18386             :     /*
   18387             :      * Messy query to collect the dependency data we need.  Note that we
   18388             :      * ignore the sub-object column, so that dependencies of or on a column
   18389             :      * look the same as dependencies of or on a whole table.
   18390             :      *
   18391             :      * PIN dependencies aren't interesting, and EXTENSION dependencies were
   18392             :      * already processed by getExtensionMembership.
   18393             :      */
   18394         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "SELECT "
   18395             :                          "classid, objid, refclassid, refobjid, deptype "
   18396             :                          "FROM pg_depend "
   18397             :                          "WHERE deptype != 'p' AND deptype != 'e'\n");
   18398             : 
   18399             :     /*
   18400             :      * Since we don't treat pg_amop entries as separate DumpableObjects, we
   18401             :      * have to translate their dependencies into dependencies of their parent
   18402             :      * opfamily.  Ignore internal dependencies though, as those will point to
   18403             :      * their parent opclass, which we needn't consider here (and if we did,
   18404             :      * it'd just result in circular dependencies).  Also, "loose" opfamily
   18405             :      * entries will have dependencies on their parent opfamily, which we
   18406             :      * should drop since they'd likewise become useless self-dependencies.
   18407             :      * (But be sure to keep deps on *other* opfamilies; see amopsortfamily.)
   18408             :      */
   18409         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "UNION ALL\n"
   18410             :                          "SELECT 'pg_opfamily'::regclass AS classid, amopfamily AS objid, refclassid, refobjid, deptype "
   18411             :                          "FROM pg_depend d, pg_amop o "
   18412             :                          "WHERE deptype NOT IN ('p', 'e', 'i') AND "
   18413             :                          "classid = 'pg_amop'::regclass AND objid = o.oid "
   18414             :                          "AND NOT (refclassid = 'pg_opfamily'::regclass AND amopfamily = refobjid)\n");
   18415             : 
   18416             :     /* Likewise for pg_amproc entries */
   18417         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "UNION ALL\n"
   18418             :                          "SELECT 'pg_opfamily'::regclass AS classid, amprocfamily AS objid, refclassid, refobjid, deptype "
   18419             :                          "FROM pg_depend d, pg_amproc p "
   18420             :                          "WHERE deptype NOT IN ('p', 'e', 'i') AND "
   18421             :                          "classid = 'pg_amproc'::regclass AND objid = p.oid "
   18422             :                          "AND NOT (refclassid = 'pg_opfamily'::regclass AND amprocfamily = refobjid)\n");
   18423             : 
   18424             :     /* Sort the output for efficiency below */
   18425         294 :     appendPQExpBufferStr(query, "ORDER BY 1,2");
   18426             : 
   18427         294 :     res = ExecuteSqlQuery(fout, query->data, PGRES_TUPLES_OK);
   18428             : 
   18429         294 :     ntups = PQntuples(res);
   18430             : 
   18431         294 :     i_classid = PQfnumber(res, "classid");
   18432         294 :     i_objid = PQfnumber(res, "objid");
   18433         294 :     i_refclassid = PQfnumber(res, "refclassid");
   18434         294 :     i_refobjid = PQfnumber(res, "refobjid");
   18435         294 :     i_deptype = PQfnumber(res, "deptype");
   18436             : 
   18437             :     /*
   18438             :      * Since we ordered the SELECT by referencing ID, we can expect that
   18439             :      * multiple entries for the same object will appear together; this saves
   18440             :      * on searches.
   18441             :      */
   18442         294 :     dobj = NULL;
   18443             : 
   18444      609254 :     for (i = 0; i < ntups; i++)
   18445             :     {
   18446             :         CatalogId   objId;
   18447             :         CatalogId   refobjId;
   18448             :         char        deptype;
   18449             :

   18540             : /*
   18541             :  * addBoundaryDependencies - add dependencies as needed to enforce the dump
   18542             :  * section boundaries.
   18543             :  */
